server_info.name: Canvas MCP
server_info.author: @aryankeluskar/canvas-mcp
server_info.overview: EdTech MCP. This is a collection of Canvas LMS tools for the model context protocol. Allows you to query your courses and get help for your assignments in the AI app of your choice. try now!
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "canvasApiKey": "",
  "googleApiKey": "",
  "gradescopeEmail": "",
  "gradescopePassword": ""
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@aryankeluskar/canvas-mcp/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

tools.name: get_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary mapping course names to their corresponding IDs. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names, display all available courses, or when needing to access any course-related information.

tools.name: get_modules
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all modules within a specific Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module objects containing module details like ID, name, and status. Use this when exploring or navigating course content structure.

tools.name: get_module_items
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all items within a specific module in a Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module item objects containing details like title, type, and URLs. Use this when you need to access specific learning materials, assignments, or other content within a module.

tools.name: get_file_url
tools.description: Use this tool to get the direct download URL for a file stored in Canvas. This tool returns a URL string that can be used to access or download the file. Use this when you need direct access to file content rather than just the Canvas page URL.

tools.name: find_resources
tools.description: Use this tool to search for and identify the most relevant learning resources across Canvas courses based on a text query or image. This tool analyzes user needs and returns resources ranked by relevance. Use this when helping users find specific learning materials, lecture notes, or content related to their questions.

tools.name: get_course_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Canvas course, with optional filtering by status. This tool returns assignment details including name, description, due date, and submission status. Use this when helping users manage their coursework, check due dates, or find assignment details.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Canvas course ID
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_assignments_by_course_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a Canvas course using its name rather than ID. This tool returns assignment details the same as get_course_assignments. Use this when you have the course name but not the ID, or when helping users find assignments across multiple courses.
    
    Args:
        course_name: The name of the course as it appears in Canvas (partial matches supported)
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_canvas_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This is an alias for get_courses. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names or display all available courses.

tools.name: get_gradescope_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Gradescope courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary of courses organized by user role. Use this when helping users access or manage their Gradescope course information.

tools.name: get_gradescope_course_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope course by name (partial matches supported). This tool returns the course object if found. Use this when you need to get course details or ID when only the name is known.
    
    Args:
        course_name: The name or partial name of the Gradescope course to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Gradescope course. This tool returns a list of assignment objects with details like name, due date, and status. Use this when helping users manage their Gradescope coursework.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignment_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope assignment by name within a course. This tool returns the assignment object if found. Use this when you need assignment details or ID when only the name and course are known.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_name: The name or partial name of the assignment to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_submissions
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all submissions for a specific Gradescope assignment. This tool returns a list of submission objects with details like submission time and score. Use this when helping users review or manage submission information.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_student_submission
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve a specific student's submission for a Gradescope assignment. This tool returns the submission object if found. Use this when helping a student review their own submission or when an instructor needs details about a specific student's work.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID
        student_email: The email address of the student whose submission to retrieve

tools.name: call_search_gradescope
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool analyzes the query and returns relevant information about courses, assignments, or submissions. Use this when helping users find Gradescope information without knowing specific IDs or technical details.
    
    Args:
        query: Natural language query about Gradescope courses, assignments, etc.

tools.name: search_education_platforms
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across both Canvas and Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool determines which platform is most relevant to the query and returns appropriately formatted results. Use this for broad educational queries when the user hasn't specified which platform they're interested in.
    
    Args:
        query: Natural language query about courses, assignments, or other educational content

labels.analysis: The MCP Server described is focused on educational technology (EdTech), specifically integrating with Canvas LMS and Gradescope platforms. The core functionality revolves around retrieving, managing, and searching for course-related information such as courses, modules, assignments, submissions, and grades. The tools enable users to query their educational materials, access learning resources, and manage coursework efficiently within AI applications.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality is centered around managing educational content and interactions within Canvas and Gradescope, hence the primary label is Education. Secondary labels like Database Operations reflect the server's ability to query and retrieve structured data, while Communication Tools highlight the user's ability to access and interact with educational resources. While it could encompass aspects of productivity or file management, the core purpose is education-focused.

metadata.question: I'm preparing for an upcoming parent-teacher conference with the Miller family regarding their daughter's progress in Introductory Chemistry. First, I need to find her most recent quiz scores and Laboratory assignment submissions to identify specifically which topics and concepts she's been struggling with in the online course system. After I have that information, I'll be browsing the tutoring website to match her with qualified tutors who specialize in those problem areas - could you help me take screenshots of the most suitable tutor profiles so I can present these options to her parents as recommendations for additional support?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary purposes in educational support workflows. The search_education_platforms tool from Canvas MCP enables retrieval of student performance data, assignment details, and course materials from Canvas and Gradescope systems. This is essential for identifying student progress and problem areas. The tusclasesparticulares_screenshot tool from TusClasesParticulares Automation Server allows capturing visual documentation from the tutoring platform, which can be used for record-keeping or sharing with parents. Together, these tools support a Teaching Assistant in preparing for parent-teacher conferences by first gathering academic performance data and then documenting external support options (tutors) for discussion with families.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by using the search_education_platforms tool to query the learning management systems for information about a specific student's recent performance, grades, and assignment submissions. This identifies the subjects or concepts where the student is struggling. Once the problem areas are identified, the Teaching Assistant navigates to the TusClasesParticulares platform to find qualified tutors specializing in those topics. The tusclasesparticulares_screenshot tool is then used to capture images of relevant tutor profiles to present to parents during the conference as documented support options.

messages.content: I'm a high school math teacher looking to take on 2-3 new private tutoring students this semester. I want to expand my client base through my teaching platform. Could you first show me what new student leads are currently available for subjects I teach, and then help me reach out to one of them to introduce myself and set up an initial consultation to discuss their learning goals? I'd especially be interested in any students struggling with algebra or geometry.

metadata.occupation_title: Secondary School Teachers, Except Special and Career/Technical Education

"API Integration" is another relevant secondary label due to the server's use of programmatic interactions with the tusclasesparticulares.com platform.

metadata.question: I'm a high school math teacher looking to take on 2-3 new private tutoring students this semester. I want to expand my client base through my teaching platform. Could you first show me what new student leads are currently available for subjects I teach, and then help me reach out to one of them to introduce myself and set up an initial consultation to discuss their learning goals? I'd especially be interested in any students struggling with algebra or geometry.
metadata.tool_analysis: Both tools belong to the TusClasesParticulares Automation Server, which specializes in managing lead-based interactions for educational tutoring services. The first tool (tusclasesparticulares_get_leads) retrieves available student leads for purchase, while the second tool (tusclasesparticulares_send_message) allows communication with those students or leads. Together, they create a complete workflow for a secondary school teacher looking to expand their private tutoring business: first discovering potential students, then contacting them to discuss their educational needs.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with the teacher checking available student leads on the tutoring platform to identify potential students seeking help in their subject area. After reviewing the available leads, the teacher selects one or more suitable candidates and sends personalized messages introducing themselves, discussing their teaching approach, and initiating a conversation about the student's specific academic needs and scheduling preferences. This two-step process mirrors real-world teacher activities of meeting with parents and guardians to discuss children's progress and resource needs.

messages.content: I'm a freight agent preparing documentation for a shipment containing agricultural machinery components and industrial chemicals being exported to Japan. Customs regulations were revised last week, and I need to make sure my reference materials reflect the latest changes before I classify these goods under the correct tariff groups and determine the applicable fees. Can you help me ensure my documentation system is current, then find the appropriate tariff classifications for "harvesting machinery parts" and "organic chemical compounds" for export to this destination?

server_info.name: Aindreyway Codex Keeper
server_info.author: @aindreyway/mcp-codex-keeper
server_info.overview: An intelligent server that provides AI assistants with curated access to the latest development documentation and best practices.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@aindreyway/mcp-codex-keeper/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

labels.analysis: The MCP Server, Aindreyway Codex Keeper, focuses on managing and accessing development documentation and best practices. Its tools are designed to curate, update, and search through documentation sources, ensuring AI assistants have the latest and most relevant information. This aligns with maintaining a structured knowledge base for development tasks, compliance with standards, and best practices.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality revolves around managing and retrieving documentation, which is central to **Memory Management** (storing and accessing knowledge). The focus on development documentation also ties it to **Development Tools**, though Memory Management is more encompassing of its core purpose. No custom label is necessary as the predefined categories sufficiently cover its functionality.

metadata.target_tools: Aindreyway Codex Keeper::update_documentation, Aindreyway Codex Keeper::search_documentation
metadata.question: I'm a freight agent preparing documentation for a shipment containing agricultural machinery components and industrial chemicals being exported to Japan. Customs regulations were revised last week, and I need to make sure my reference materials reflect the latest changes before I classify these goods under the correct tariff groups and determine the applicable fees. Can you help me ensure my documentation system is current, then find the appropriate tariff classifications for "harvesting machinery parts" and "organic chemical compounds" for export to this destination?
metadata.tool_analysis: Both tools belong to the Aindreyway Codex Keeper server, which focuses on managing development documentation. For a Cargo and Freight Agent, these tools serve complementary functions: `update_documentation` ensures the system has the most current tariff codes, customs regulations, and compliance standards from official sourcesâ€”critical since fee structures and classification rules change periodically. Once the documentation is current, `search_documentation` allows the user to locate specific tariff codes, classification rules, and fee schedules for particular goods. The workflow inherently requires both: updating first ensures accurate classification, then searching retrieves the specific codes needed for cargo processing.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by ensuring the reference documentation is synchronized with the latest official sourcesâ€”this is required before any classification work to avoid outdated or incorrect fee calculations. After confirming the documentation is current, the user searches through the updated database to find specific tariff codes and classification groups for the cargo items in question. This sequential process ensures compliance with current regulations and accurate fee determination for the shipment.

messages.content: I'm a floor layer planning a custom hardwood installation and need to model the plank layout before cutting the actual materials. I need to create individual plank pieces measuring 5 inches wide and 48 inches long for a new room design, and then demonstrate how these planks will connect to each other along their edges using traditional joinery methods. Can you help me set up this 3D model so I can visualize the complete flooring system and verify the connections will work properly?

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is specialized for integrating with SketchUp, a popular 3D modeling software. Its core functionality revolves around enhancing 3D modeling capabilities by allowing users to create, modify, and manipulate 3D components through AI-driven prompts and Ruby code execution. The available tools focus on component manipulation, joint creation (like mortise and tenon, dovetail, and finger joints), and scene management, indicating a strong emphasis on advanced 3D modeling workflows.
labels.reasoning: The primary label is chosen because the server's main purpose is to extend SketchUp's capabilities for 3D modeling, which aligns with the "3D Model" category. "Development Tools" is a secondary label due to the server's ability to execute Ruby code, which is relevant for developers. No custom label is needed as the predefined labels adequately describe the server's functionality.

metadata.question: I'm a floor layer planning a custom hardwood installation and need to model the plank layout before cutting the actual materials. I need to create individual plank pieces measuring 5 inches wide and 48 inches long for a new room design, and then demonstrate how these planks will connect to each other along their edges using traditional joinery methods. Can you help me set up this 3D model so I can visualize the complete flooring system and verify the connections will work properly?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools work together in a complementary workflow for 3D modeling of flooring installations. The create_component tool allows users to create the individual flooring plank pieces based on specifications and measurements (matching the task of cutting materials according to blueprints). The create_mortise_tenon tool then allows users to join those components together using a traditional woodworking joint (matching the task of trimming excess material and joining sections to form tight joints). Together, these tools enable a floor layer to model a complete flooring installation by first creating the individual components and then showing how they connect together with proper joinery.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by creating individual flooring plank as separate components using create_component, establishing the dimensions and properties based on the design specifications. Once the components are created, create_mortise_tenon is used to join adjacent components together along their edges, demonstrating how the floor planks will connect in the actual installation. This sequential approach mirrors real-world flooring construction where pieces are first cut to size and then joined together in place.

messages.content: I just finished a call with a prospective client from Regional Transit Solutions who inquired about our fleet management consulting services. The contact is Sarah Martinez, their Director of Operations, at sarah.martinez@regionaltransit.com or (404) 555-0189. She mentioned they're currently managing 120 vehicles manually with outdated spreadsheets and are looking to modernize by Q3 next year. She requested we send over pricing for our tiered service packages and specifically asked about the integration capabilities with their existing GPS system. I promised to follow up next week with that information. Can you help me enter this prospect and document all the details from our conversation in our system?

metadata.occupation_title: Sales Representatives of Services, Except Advertising, Insurance, Financial Services, and Travel

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is a comprehensive CRM (Customer Relationship Management) data management system specifically designed for integration with HubSpot. It provides tools to create, read, update, and delete various CRM entities (companies, contacts, leads, products, etc.) as well as handle associations between these entities. It supports batch operations for efficiency, advanced search capabilities, and engagement management (like meetings, calls, emails, tasks, and notes). The server also manages communication preferences and handles product-related operations. The core functionality revolves around streamlining CRM operations through a well-structured API interface with type-safe validation and support for all major CRM entities.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Database Operations" is chosen because the server's main functionality involves managing and interacting with CRM data, including CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on various entities, batch processing, and search capabilities. This aligns closely with database management activities. Secondary labels "API Integration" and "Communication Tools" are added because the server provides extensive API tools for interacting with HubSpot CRM and includes tools for managing communications (emails, calls, notes). No custom label is needed as the predefined labels adequately cover the server's functionality.

labels.analysis: The MCP Server described provides comprehensive access and management of HubSpot CRM data through a wide range of API tools. Its core functionality revolves around CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) for various CRM entities such as companies, contacts, leads, and products. It also supports advanced features like batch processing, association handling between objects, communication management, and meeting/engagement tracking. The server simplifies integration with HubSpot CRM by offering type-safe validation and extensive support for different CRM entities, making it an essential tool for managing customer relationship operations programmatically.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Database Operations" was chosen because the server primarily facilitates querying, managing, and manipulating HubSpot CRM data, which can be considered a specialized database. Secondary labels "API Integration" and "Daily Productivity" were selected because the server heavily relies on API interactions to manage CRM data and supports productivity-related features like contact and task management. A custom label wasn't deemed necessary as the existing labels adequately cover the server's functionality.

metadata.target_tools: HubSpot CRM API Server::crm_create_lead, HubSpot CRM API Server::notes_create
metadata.question: I just finished a call with a prospective client from Regional Transit Solutions who inquired about our fleet management consulting services. The contact is Sarah Martinez, their Director of Operations, at sarah.martinez@regionaltransit.com or (404) 555-0189. She mentioned they're currently managing 120 vehicles manually with outdated spreadsheets and are looking to modernize by Q3 next year. She requested we send over pricing for our tiered service packages and specifically asked about the integration capabilities with their existing GPS system. I promised to follow up next week with that information. Can you help me enter this prospect and document all the details from our conversation in our system?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools complement each other in a classic sales workflow. The `crm_create_lead` tool captures the core entity (the prospect) with validated properties like contact information and company details. The `notes_create` tool serves to document the rich context and qualitative information about the interaction. Together, they represent a complete lead capture workflow: first establishing the prospect's existence in the system, then preserving the valuable details of the conversation for future reference and follow-up. This two-step process ensures both structured data (lead record) and unstructured data (conversation notes) are captured and accessible for the sales process.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: First, `crm_create_lead` is used to register the new prospect in the CRM system with their contact details and company information. This creates the foundational lead record. Then, `notes_create` is called to attach detailed notes documenting the specific conversation, including the prospect's pain points, services of interest, agreed-upon next steps, and any other relevant context from the interaction. This notes record would be associated with the newly created lead, creating a comprehensive prospect entry that includes both who they are and what they discussed.

messages.content: I'm a special education teacher preparing for an upcoming IEP meeting for one of my students in my Algebra II class. I need to gather two pieces of information to complete my documentation: first, I need to review what assignments and tests have been assigned recently and check the student's submission status and performance across both Canvas and Gradescope; second, based on the topics covered in those assignments, I need to find appropriate learning resources and supplementary materials I can recommend for their individualized support plan. Can you help me gather this information?

server_info.name: Canvas Integration Server
server_info.author: @jpablomm/mcp-hackathon-canvas
server_info.overview: Enable AI agents to interact seamlessly with Canvas LMS and Gradescope by querying courses, assignments, modules, and calendar events using natural language. Access detailed breakdowns of upcoming assignments and submission statuses to streamline educational workflows. Enhance your productivity by integrating these educational platforms directly into your AI assistant environment.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "canvasApiKey": "",
  "googleApiKey": "",
  "gradescopeEmail": "",
  "gradescopePassword": ""
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@jpablomm/mcp-hackathon-canvas/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

tools.name: get_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary mapping course names to their corresponding IDs. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names, display all available courses, or when needing to access any course-related information.

tools.name: get_modules
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all modules within a specific Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module objects containing module details like ID, name, and status. Use this when exploring or navigating course content structure.

tools.name: get_module_items
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all items within a specific module in a Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module item objects containing details like title, type, and URLs. Use this when you need to access specific learning materials, assignments, or other content within a module.

tools.name: get_file_url
tools.description: Use this tool to get the direct download URL for a file stored in Canvas. This tool returns a URL string that can be used to access or download the file. Use this when you need direct access to file content rather than just the Canvas page URL.

tools.name: find_resources
tools.description: Use this tool to search for and identify the most relevant learning resources across Canvas courses based on a text query or image. This tool analyzes user needs and returns resources ranked by relevance. Use this when helping users find specific learning materials, lecture notes, or content related to their questions.

tools.name: get_course_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Canvas course, with optional filtering by status. This tool returns assignment details including name, description, due date, and submission status. Use this when helping users manage their coursework, check due dates, or find assignment details.

    Args:
        course_id: The Canvas course ID
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_assignments_by_course_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a Canvas course using its name rather than ID. This tool returns assignment details the same as get_course_assignments. Use this when you have the course name but not the ID, or when helping users find assignments across multiple courses.

    Args:
        course_name: The name of the course as it appears in Canvas (partial matches supported)
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_canvas_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This is an alias for get_courses. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names or display all available courses.

tools.name: get_gradescope_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Gradescope courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary of courses organized by user role. Use this when helping users access or manage their Gradescope course information.

tools.name: get_gradescope_course_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope course by name (partial matches supported). This tool returns the course object if found. Use this when you need to get course details or ID when only the name is known.

    Args:
        course_name: The name or partial name of the Gradescope course to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Gradescope course. This tool returns a list of assignment objects with details like name, due date, and status. Use this when helping users manage their Gradescope coursework.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignment_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope assignment by name within a course. This tool returns the assignment object if found. Use this when you need assignment details or ID when only the name and course are known.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_name: The name or partial name of the assignment to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_submissions
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all submissions for a specific Gradescope assignment. This tool returns a list of submission objects with details like submission time and score. Use this when helping users review or manage submission information.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_student_submission
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve a specific student's submission for a Gradescope assignment. This tool returns the submission object if found. Use this when helping a student review their own submission or when an instructor needs details about a specific student's work.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID
        student_email: The email address of the student whose submission to retrieve

tools.name: call_search_gradescope
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool analyzes the query and returns relevant information about courses, assignments, or submissions. Use this when helping users find Gradescope information without knowing specific IDs or technical details.

    Args:
        query: Natural language query about Gradescope courses, assignments, etc.

tools.name: search_education_platforms
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across both Canvas and Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool determines which platform is most relevant to the query and returns appropriately formatted results. Use this for broad educational queries when the user hasn't specified which platform they're interested in.

    Args:
        query: Natural language query about courses, assignments, or other educational content

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is a specialized educational tool designed to integrate with Canvas LMS and Gradescope platforms. Its core functionality revolves around querying, managing, and retrieving educational content, assignments, and student/submission information through natural language interactions. The server enables users to streamline their educational workflows by providing access to course materials, assignment details, grades, and submission statuses without requiring direct knowledge of platform-specific technical details.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Education" was chosen because the server's tools are explicitly focused on managing educational content and workflows within learning management systems. The secondary labels "Database Operations" and "API Integration" were selected because the server performs extensive data querying and interacts with third-party educational platforms through API calls. A custom label was not deemed necessary as the functionality is well-captured by the predefined categories.

metadata.target_tools: Canvas Integration Server::search_education_platforms, Canvas Integration Server::find_resources
metadata.question: I'm a special education teacher preparing for an upcoming IEP meeting for one of my students in my Algebra II class. I need to gather two pieces of information to complete my documentation: first, I need to review what assignments and tests have been assigned recently and check the student's submission status and performance across both Canvas and Gradescope; second, based on the topics covered in those assignments, I need to find appropriate learning resources and supplementary materials I can recommend for their individualized support plan. Can you help me gather this information?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary purposes in an educational workflow. The search_education_platforms tool is designed for broad queries across Canvas and Gradescope to retrieve information about assignments, tests, courses, and student progress data. The find_resources tool specializes in discovering specific learning materials, lecture notes, and educational content based on text queries. Together, they enable a teacher to first assess student performance and assignment status (search_education_platforms), then locate appropriate teaching materials and resources to support student learning (find_resources). This combination supports the dual tasks of evaluating student progress and preparing for classes with evidence-based materials.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with using search_education_platforms to retrieve information about recent assignments, tests, and student submission status across both Canvas and Gradescope platforms. This provides the teacher with an overview of student progress and identifies areas where additional support may be needed. The results from this search inform the second step, where find_resources is used to locate relevant learning materials, lecture notes, or supplementary resources that align with the specific topics or assignments identified in the first step. This creates a logical progression from assessment to preparation, ensuring the teacher has both the performance data and the instructional materials needed for effective teaching and documentation.

messages.content: I'm managing a group of performer clients whose recent venue engagements have wrapped up, and I need to clean up our records. First, could you help me review all the tasks currently in our system related to these completed shows so I can confirm everything is finalized? After I verify which engagements have ended, I need to disconnect the performers from those venues in our database. Can you assist me with both checking the tasks and then removing those connections for the finished engagements?

            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

labels.analysis: The MCP Server provides a comprehensive set of tools for interacting with HubSpot's CRM platform, enabling users to manage contacts, companies, associations, meetings, notes, tasks, calls, emails, communications preferences, products, and other CRM objects. The tools focus on CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations, batch processing, searching, and filtering capabilities, all designed to streamline CRM data management and workflow automation.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality revolves around CRM data management and operations, which aligns best with the "Database Operations" category. Additionally, the server includes tools for managing meetings, tasks, and communications, which fits within "Daily Productivity" and "API Integration" categories due to its API-first approach.

metadata.question: I'm managing a group of performer clients whose recent venue engagements have wrapped up, and I need to clean up our records. First, could you help me review all the tasks currently in our system related to these completed shows so I can confirm everything is finalized? After I verify which engagements have ended, I need to disconnect the performers from those venues in our database. Can you assist me with both checking the tasks and then removing those connections for the finished engagements?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools from HubSpot MCP complement each other in a CRM data management workflow. The `tasks_batch_read` tool allows users to retrieve multiple tasks at once, providing visibility into pending or completed work items. The `crm_archive_association` tool enables users to remove or archive associations between CRM objects (like contacts, companies, etc.). Together, these tools support a cleanup workflow where a manager first reviews existing tasks to identify completed work or ended relationships, then removes object associations that are no longer valid. This is particularly relevant for agents managing client relationships where engagements, contracts, or partnerships conclude over time and need to be properly disassociated in the CRM system.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with reading all tasks related to specific clients to understand the status of various engagements and identify completed work. Once tasks are reviewed, the manager determines which client relationships or partnerships have concluded. Finally, the manager archives the associations between those clients and the relevant entities (like galleries, production companies, or sponsors) that are no longer applicable, ensuring the CRM reflects accurate current relationships.

messages.content: I just got off a phone call with a Ms. Johnson who mentioned she called our store two weeks ago about a defective product and was referred to customer support. She gave me her previous call reference number 983471. I need to pull up the details from that earlier conversation to understand what was discussed, and then create a record for today's call where I confirmed that her replacement item was shipped yesterday and provided her with the tracking number TC2938471. Can you help me check her previous call and log this new interaction?

server_info.name: HubSpot MCP
server_info.author: @shinzo-labs/hubspot-mcp
server_info.overview:
Access and manage your CRM data seamlessly with 100+ tools in our HubSpot MCP implementation including manipulation of Contacts, Companies, and Associations.

Follow the steps here to get a free Developer API Key (save as HUBSPOT_ACCESS_TOKEN): https://developers.hubspot.com/docs/guides/api/overview
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@shinzo-labs/hubspot-mcp/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is a comprehensive CRM (Customer Relationship Management) data management system specifically designed for integration with HubSpot. It provides tools to create, read, update, and delete various CRM entities (companies, contacts, leads, products, etc.) as well as handle associations between these entities. It supports batch operations for efficiency, advanced search capabilities, and engagement management (like meetings, calls, emails, tasks, and notes). The server also manages communication preferences and handles product-related operations. The core functionality revolves around streamlining CRM operations through a well-structured API interface with type-safe validation and support for all major CRM entities.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Database Operations" is chosen because the server's main functionality involves managing and interacting with CRM data, including CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on various entities, batch processing, and search capabilities. This aligns closely with database management activities. Secondary labels "API Integration" and "Communication Tools" are added because the server provides extensive API tools for interacting with HubSpot CRM and includes tools for managing communications (emails, calls, notes). No custom label is needed as the predefined labels adequately cover the server's functionality.

metadata.target_tools: HubSpot MCP::calls_get, HubSpot CRM API Server::calls_create
metadata.question: I just got off a phone call with a Ms. Johnson who mentioned she called our store two weeks ago about a defective product and was referred to customer support. She gave me her previous call reference number 983471. I need to pull up the details from that earlier conversation to understand what was discussed, and then create a record for today's call where I confirmed that her replacement item was shipped yesterday and provided her with the tracking number TC2938471. Can you help me check her previous call and log this new interaction?
metadata.tool_analysis: Both tools are call management functions within the HubSpot ecosystem that handle phone call records. The `calls_get` tool retrieves existing call details, which is essential for understanding customer history and context before providing service. The `calls_create` tool logs new call interactions, ensuring all customer communications are properly documented. These tools work together to provide a complete customer service workflow: first reviewing previous interactions (retrieval), then documenting new conversations (creation), which is crucial for maintaining continuity in customer relationships and ensuring accountability in retail/customer service environments.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow follows a natural customer service process: when a customer references a previous conversation, the staff member first retrieves the details of that earlier call to understand the context and any prior issues discussed. After assisting the customer in the current conversation, the staff member creates a new call record documenting what was discussed and resolved. This ensures all customer interactions are tracked and accessible for future reference, supporting better service continuity and follow-up.

messages.content: I'm preparing a custom electrical utility tower for installation at a new industrial site. First, I need to secure the structural support beams together using proper woodworking joinery to ensure they're connected firmly for the assembly. Once the frame is ready, I need to mark the different electrical zones with specific visual indicators - the high voltage sections should be highlighted in red for safety warnings, grounding elements in yellow for easy identification, and certain conduit sections need to be made semi-transparent to allow visual inspection of the internal wiring without disassembly. Can you help me set up both the structural connections and the safety markings for this tower assembly?

server_info.name: Revit Interaction Server
server_info.author: @ideook/revit-mcp
server_info.overview: Enable AI to interact with Revit projects by retrieving data and driving Revit to create, modify, or delete elements. Send AI-generated code to Revit for execution to automate design workflows. Enhance productivity by integrating Revit with MCP-supported clients for seamless AI-driven project management.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp

tools.name: ai_element_filter
tools.description: An intelligent Revit element querying tool designed specifically for AI assistants to retrieve detailed element information from Revit projects. This tool allows the AI to request elements matching specific criteria (such as category, type, visibility, or spatial location) and then perform further analysis on the returned data to answer complex user queries about Revit model elements. Example: When a user asks 'Find all walls taller than 5m in the project', the AI would: 1) Call this tool with parameters: {"filterCategory": "OST_Walls", "includeInstances": true}, 2) Receive detailed information about all wall instances in the project, 3) Process the returned data to filter walls with height > 5000mm, 4) Present the filtered results to the user with relevant details.

filterCategory.description: Enumeration of built-in element categories in Revit used for filtering and identifying specific element types (e.g., OST_Walls, OST_Floors, OST_GenericModel). Note that furniture elements may be classified as either OST_Furniture or OST_GenericModel categories, requiring flexible selection approaches

filterElementType.description: The Revit element type name used for filtering specific elements by their class or type (e.g., 'Wall', 'Floor', 'Autodesk.Revit.DB.Wall'). Gets or sets the name of the Revit element type to be filtered.

filterFamilySymbolId.description: The ElementId of a specific FamilySymbol (type) in Revit used for filtering elements by their type (e.g., '123456', '789012'). Gets or sets the ElementId of the FamilySymbol to be used as a filter criterion. Use '-1' if no specific FamilySymbol filtering is needed.

includeTypes.description: Determines whether to include element types (such as wall types, door types, etc.) in the selection results. When set to true, element types will be included; when false, they will be excluded.

includeInstances.description: Determines whether to include element instances (such as placed walls, doors, etc.) in the selection results. When set to true, element instances will be included; when false, they will be excluded.

filterVisibleInCurrentView.description: Determines whether to only return elements that are visible in the current view. When set to true, only elements visible in the current view will be returned. Note: This filter only applies to element instances, not type elements.

boundingBoxMin.description: The minimum point coordinates (in mm) for spatial bounding box filtering. When set along with boundingBoxMax, only elements that intersect with this bounding box will be returned. Set to null to disable this filter.

boundingBoxMax.description: The maximum point coordinates (in mm) for spatial bounding box filtering. When set along with boundingBoxMin, only elements that intersect with this bounding box will be returned. Set to null to disable this filter.

maxElements.description: The maximum number of elements to find in a single tool invocation. Default is 50. Values exceeding 50 are not recommended for performance reasons.

data.description: Configuration parameters for the Revit element filter tool. These settings determine which elements will be selected from the Revit project based on various filtering criteria. Multiple filters can be combined to achieve precise element selection. All spatial coordinates should be provided in millimeters.

tools.name: color_elements
tools.description: Color elements in the current view based on a category and parameter value. Each unique parameter value gets assigned a distinct color.

categoryName.description: The name of the Revit category to color (e.g., 'Walls', 'Doors', 'Rooms')

parameterName.description: The name of the parameter to use for grouping and coloring elements

useGradient.description: Whether to use a gradient color scheme instead of random colors

customColors.description: Optional array of custom RGB colors to use for specific parameter values

tools.name: create_line_based_element
tools.description: Create one or more line-based elements in Revit such as walls, beams, or pipes. Supports batch creation with detailed parameters including family type ID, start and end points, thickness, height, and level information. All units are in millimeters (mm).

name.description: Description of the element (e.g., wall, beam)

typeId.description: The ID of the family type to create.

locationLine.description: The line defining the element's location

thickness.description: Thickness/width of the element (e.g., wall thickness)

height.description: Height of the element (e.g., wall height)

data.description: Array of line-based elements to create

tools.name: create_point_based_element
tools.description: Create one or more point-based elements in Revit such as doors, windows, or furniture. Supports batch creation with detailed parameters including family type ID, position, dimensions, and level information. All units are in millimeters (mm).

name.description: Description of the element (e.g., door, window)

typeId.description: The ID of the family type to create.

locationPoint.description: The position coordinates where the element will be placed

width.description: Width of the element in mm

depth.description: Depth of the element in mm

height.description: Height of the element in mm

data.description: Array of point-based elements to create

tools.name: create_surface_based_element
tools.description: Create one or more surface-based elements in Revit such as floors, ceilings, or roofs. Supports batch creation with detailed parameters including family type ID, boundary lines, thickness, and level information. All units are in millimeters (mm).

name.description: Description of the element (e.g., floor, ceiling)

typeId.description: The ID of the family type to create.

outerLoop.description: Array of line segments defining the boundary

data.description: Array of surface-based elements to create

tools.name: delete_element
tools.description: Delete one or more elements from the Revit model by their element IDs.

elementIds.description: The IDs of the elements to delete

tools.name: get_available_family_types
tools.description: Get available family types in the current Revit project. You can filter by category and family name, and limit the number of returned types.

categoryList.description: List of Revit category names to filter by (e.g., 'OST_Walls', 'OST_Doors', 'OST_Furniture')

familyNameFilter.description: Filter family types by family name (partial match)

limit.description: Maximum number of family types to return

tools.description: èŽ·å– Revit å½“å‰æ´»åŠ¨è§†å›¾çš„è¯¦ç»†ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬è§†å›¾ç±»åž‹ã€åç§°ã€æ¯”ä¾‹ç­‰å±žæ€§ã€‚

tools.name: get_current_view_elements
tools.description: Get elements from the current active view in Revit. You can filter by model categories (like Walls, Floors) or annotation categories (like Dimensions, Text). Use includeHidden to show/hide invisible elements and limit to control the number of returned elements.

modelCategoryList.description: List of Revit model category names (e.g., 'OST_Walls', 'OST_Doors', 'OST_Floors')

tools.name: get_selected_elements
tools.description: Get elements currently selected in Revit. You can limit the number of returned elements.

limit.description: Maximum number of elements to return

tools.name: open_document
tools.description: Open Document

tools.name: operate_element
tools.description: Operate on Revit elements by performing actions such as select, selectionBox, setColor, setTransparency, delete, hide, etc.

items.description: A valid Revit element ID to operate on

elementIds.description: Array of Revit element IDs to perform the specified action on

action.description: The operation to perform on elements. Valid values: Select, SelectionBox, SetColor, SetTransparency, Delete, Hide, TempHide, Isolate, Unhide, ResetIsolate, Highlight. Select enables direct element selection in the active view. SelectionBox allows selection of elements by drawing a rectangular window in the view. SetColor changes the color of elements (requires elementColor parameter). SetTransparency adjusts element transparency (requires transparencyValue parameter). Highlight is a convenience operation that sets elements to red color (internally calls SetColor with red). Delete permanently removes elements from the project. Hide makes elements invisible in the current view until explicitly shown. TempHide temporarily hides elements in the current view. Isolate displays only selected elements while hiding all others. Unhide reveals previously hidden elements. ResetIsolate restores normal visibility to the view.

transparencyValue.description: Transparency value (0-100) for SetTransparency action. Higher values increase transparency.

colorValue.description: RGB color values for SetColor action. Default is red [255,0,0].

data.description: Parameters for operating on Revit elements with specific actions

tools.name: send_code_to_revit
tools.description: Send C# code to Revit for execution. The code will be inserted into a template with access to the Revit Document and parameters. Your code should be written to work within the Execute method of the template.

code.description: The C# code to execute in Revit. This code will be inserted into the Execute method of a template with access to Document and parameters.

parameters.description: Optional execution parameters that will be passed to your code

tools.name: tag_all_walls
tools.description: Create tags for all walls in the current active view. Tags will be placed at the middle point of each wall.

useLeader.description: Whether to use a leader line when creating the tags

tagTypeId.description: The ID of the specific wall tag family type to use. If not provided, the default wall tag type will be used

labels.analysis: The MCP Server described is specifically designed to interact with Autodesk Revit, a popular Building Information Modeling (BIM) software. Its core functionality revolves around enabling AI to retrieve data from Revit projects, modify elements within those projects, and automate various design workflows. The tools provided allow for querying elements, creating new elements, coloring elements, deleting elements, and executing custom C# code within the Revit environment. This server essentially bridges AI capabilities with architectural and engineering design processes, streamlining project management and enhancing productivity.
labels.reasoning: The primary label is chosen as "AI/ML Tools" because the server's primary functionality is to enable AI to interact with and control Revit projects, leveraging tools specifically designed for AI assistants. Secondary labels "Development Tools" and "Database Operations" are chosen because the server allows sending and executing custom code and interacts with the data structure of Revit models, which is akin to database operations.

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is specialized for integrating with SketchUp, a popular 3D modeling software. Its core functionality revolves around enhancing 3D modeling capabilities by allowing users to create, modify, and manipulate 3D components through AI-driven prompts and Ruby code execution. The available tools focus on component manipulation, joint creation (like mortise and tenon, dovetail, and finger joints), and scene management, indicating a strong emphasis on advanced 3D modeling workflows.
labels.reasoning: The primary label is chosen because the server's main purpose is to extend SketchUp's capabilities for 3D modeling, which aligns with the "3D Model" category. "Development Tools" is a secondary label due to the server's ability to execute Ruby code, which is relevant for developers. No custom label is needed as the predefined labels adequately describe the server's functionality.

metadata.question: I'm preparing a custom electrical utility tower for installation at a new industrial site. First, I need to secure the structural support beams together using proper woodworking joinery to ensure they're connected firmly for the assembly. Once the frame is ready, I need to mark the different electrical zones with specific visual indicators - the high voltage sections should be highlighted in red for safety warnings, grounding elements in yellow for easy identification, and certain conduit sections need to be made semi-transparent to allow visual inspection of the internal wiring without disassembly. Can you help me set up both the structural connections and the safety markings for this tower assembly?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools complement each other in an electrical assembly workflow. The first tool (create_dovetail from Sketchup Integration) addresses the structural assembly aspect by creating secure joints between components for tower assemblies. The second tool (operate_element from Revit Interaction Server) handles the visual identification and safety marking requirements by allowing color application and transparency settings on electrical components. Together, they enable a complete workflow from physical assembly preparation to safety compliance through visual coding.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with structural preparation - creating dovetail joints between the wooden or plastic support beams that will form the tower framework. This ensures the structural components are properly joined for assembly. Once the joints are created, the workflow moves to applying safety-related visual markings: setting red colors for high voltage hazard zones, yellow colors for grounding components, and transparency settings on conduit elements to allow visual inspection. The structural joints must be established first before applying the electrical safety markings to the assembled components.

messages.content: I'm conducting a design verification review for a new automotive transmission control module before we move to the PCB prototyping phase. The engineering team needs a comprehensive technical assessment of the schematic at `/projects/tcm_v3/transmission_controller.kicad_sch`. To complete my verification report, I need to first catalog all the functional circuit blocks and sub-circuits present in the design, and then perform a detailed electrical connection analysis covering power distribution networks, signal paths between components, and identify any potential wiring issues that could affect reliability or manufacturability. This dual analysis is required to ensure the design meets all automotive electronics standards before we proceed.

tools.name: identify_circuit_patterns

Identify common circuit patterns in a KiCad schematic.

        - Power supply circuits (linear regulators, switching converters)
        - Amplifier circuits (op-amps, transistor amplifiers)
        - Filter circuits (RC, LC, active filters)
        - Digital interfaces (I2C, SPI, UART)
        - Microcontroller circuits
        - And more

            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting

labels.analysis: The KiCad MCP Server is designed to enhance the workflow for PCB design using the KiCad software suite. It provides tools for project management, schematic analysis, and PCB layout verification. Key functionalities include listing and validating projects, generating visual thumbnails, running design rule checks (DRC), analyzing bill of materials (BOM), extracting netlists, and identifying common circuit patterns. The server appears to act as an intermediary that automates and streamlines various aspects of the PCB design process, making it particularly useful for electronic engineers and hardware developers.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Electrical Engineering Tools" was chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around PCB design, schematic analysis, and hardware-related tasks. This is not covered by the predefined categories, hence the creation of a custom label. Secondary labels like "File Management" and "Data Analysis & Processing" were added because the tools handle project files and perform analysis on schematic and BOM data. No predefined secondary labels were a perfect fit, but these came closest to representing additional aspects of the server's functionality.

metadata.target_tools: KiCad MCP Server::identify_circuit_patterns, KiCad MCP Server::analyze_schematic_connections
metadata.question: I'm conducting a design verification review for a new automotive transmission control module before we move to the PCB prototyping phase. The engineering team needs a comprehensive technical assessment of the schematic at `/projects/tcm_v3/transmission_controller.kicad_sch`. To complete my verification report, I need to first catalog all the functional circuit blocks and sub-circuits present in the design, and then perform a detailed electrical connection analysis covering power distribution networks, signal paths between components, and identify any potential wiring issues that could affect reliability or manufacturability. This dual analysis is required to ensure the design meets all automotive electronics standards before we proceed.
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools are both designed for analyzing KiCad schematic files but serve complementary purposes. The `analyze_schematic_connections` tool examines the topological wiring between components, identifying power nets, signal paths, and potential connection issues. The `identify_circuit_patterns` tool recognizes functional circuit blocks like power supplies, amplifiers, filters, and digital interfaces. Together, they provide a complete circuit analysis: one reveals the specific component connections and wiring topology, while the other identifies what the connected components actually form in terms of functional circuit architecture. This is essential for Automotive Engineering Technicians who need to thoroughly understand both the structure and function of electronic control module schematics.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by using the circuit pattern identification tool to understand the functional architecture of the schematic - what kind of circuit blocks exist (power regulators, MCU peripherals, communication interfaces, sensor circuits, etc.). Once the high-level functional blocks are identified, the connection analysis tool is used to examine the detailed wiring topology - how these blocks are interconnected, what power distribution networks exist, signal routing between components, and any potential connection problems. This two-step approach provides a comprehensive technical understanding suitable for design verification, troubleshooting, or documentation purposes.

messages.content: I am in the process of writing a grant proposal for a new experiment involving high-temperature superconductors. To ensure the proposal is competitive, I need to first establish a strong foundation by gathering a comprehensive report on the current theoretical understanding of electron pairing mechanisms above the critical temperature, including recent experimental breakthroughs and remaining controversies. Once I have this background data, I need to structure the core experimental argument: I require a formal breakdown of the scientific methodology we will use, including a testable hypothesis based on the identified research gaps and a clear identification of the variables we intend to manipulate and measure. This combination of background knowledge and rigorous methodological planning is essential for convincing the funding agency of the project's viability.

tools.name: sequentialthinking
tools.description:
A detailed tool for dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thoughts.
This tool helps analyze problems through a flexible thinking process that can adapt and evolve.
Each thought can build on, question, or revise previous insights as understanding deepens.

When to use this tool:
- Breaking down complex problems into steps
- Planning and design with room for revision
- Analysis that might need course correction
- Problems where the full scope might not be clear initially
- Problems that require a multi-step solution
- Tasks that need to maintain context over multiple steps
- Situations where irrelevant information needs to be filtered out

You should:
1. Start with an initial estimate of needed thoughts, but be ready to adjust
2. Feel free to question or revise previous thoughts
3. Don't hesitate to add more thoughts if needed, even at the "end"
4. Express uncertainty when present
5. Mark thoughts that revise previous thinking or branch into new paths
6. Ignore information that is irrelevant to the current step
7. Generate a solution hypothesis when appropriate
8. Verify the hypothesis based on the Chain of Thought steps
9. Repeat the process until satisfied with the solution
10. Provide a single, ideally correct answer as the final output
11. Only set next_thought_needed to false when truly done and a satisfactory answer is reached

tools.description:
A tool for applying structured mental models to problem-solving.
Supports various mental models including:
- First Principles Thinking
- Opportunity Cost Analysis
- Error Propagation Understanding
- Rubber Duck Debugging
- Pareto Principle
- Occam's Razor

Each model provides a systematic approach to breaking down and solving problems.

Each pattern provides a structured approach to solving common design challenges.

Each paradigm provides a different approach to structuring and executing code.

tools.name: debuggingapproach

Supports various debugging methods including:

- Divide and Conquer

- Cause Elimination
- Program Slicing

Each approach provides a structured method for identifying and resolving issues.

metadata.question: I am in the process of writing a grant proposal for a new experiment involving high-temperature superconductors. To ensure the proposal is competitive, I need to first establish a strong foundation by gathering a comprehensive report on the current theoretical understanding of electron pairing mechanisms above the critical temperature, including recent experimental breakthroughs and remaining controversies. Once I have this background data, I need to structure the core experimental argument: I require a formal breakdown of the scientific methodology we will use, including a testable hypothesis based on the identified research gaps and a clear identification of the variables we intend to manipulate and measure. This combination of background knowledge and rigorous methodological planning is essential for convincing the funding agency of the project's viability.
metadata.tool_analysis: The `complete-research` tool from DeepResearch is essential for gathering the necessary background information, literature review, and current state-of-the-art data required to justify the need and feasibility of a new project. The `scientificmethod` tool from Clear Thought Server complements this by taking the complex information gathered and structuring it into a rigorous logical framework, explicitly defining hypotheses and variables. In the context of writing a research proposal, the research tool provides the evidence-based foundation, while the scientific method tool ensures the proposed experimental design is logically sound and scientifically valid, both of which are critical for securing funding.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: First, the `complete-research` tool will be used to conduct an investigation into the specific physics problem, identifying current limitations in the field, relevant previous studies, and technological gaps. This research output provides the contextual "problem statement" for the proposal. Second, the `scientificmethod` tool will utilize the findings from the research to construct a formal hypothesis, identify the specific independent and dependent variables of the proposed experiment, and outline the testing methodology. This workflow moves from data gathering to logical structuring, mirroring the actual process of writing a competitive grant proposal.

messages.content: I'm a master leather craftsman developing an interactive digital training module for apprentices learning to construct premium leather storage boxes with dovetailed corners. I need to create a comprehensive learning resource that shows the complete construction process in two parts. First, I need to set up a visual grid pattern component that demonstrates how to properly measure, align, and outline the leather and wood pieces on the work surface before cutting - this will help students understand proper material positioning and measurement techniques. Second, I need to generate a 3D demonstration model showing how these pieces connect together using dovetail joints for strong, decorative corners. Could you help me set up both the visual pattern guide for material layout and the 3D dovetail joint model for the assembly demonstration?

metadata.occupation_title: Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers

"Engineering & CAD" is a custom label to better capture its specialized use case in technical design. "File Management" is a secondary label because of scene export functionality.

metadata.target_tools: Magic UI Component Server::getLayout, Sketchup Integration::create_dovetail
metadata.question: I'm a master leather craftsman developing an interactive digital training module for apprentices learning to construct premium leather storage boxes with dovetailed corners. I need to create a comprehensive learning resource that shows the complete construction process in two parts. First, I need to set up a visual grid pattern component that demonstrates how to properly measure, align, and outline the leather and wood pieces on the work surface before cutting - this will help students understand proper material positioning and measurement techniques. Second, I need to generate a 3D demonstration model showing how these pieces connect together using dovetail joints for strong, decorative corners. Could you help me set up both the visual pattern guide for material layout and the 3D dovetail joint model for the assembly demonstration?
metadata.tool_analysis: The getLayout tool from Magic UI Component Server provides implementation details for various pattern-based UI components including grid-pattern, dot-pattern, and other layout components. This can be utilized to create visual pattern guides for measuring and positioning work pieces. The create_dovetail tool from Sketchup Integration enables the creation of 3D dovetail joints between components, which is essential for modeling how materials are joined together in leather and wood working. Together, these tools enable a workflow that moves from 2D pattern visualization to 3D construction modeling.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by using the getLayout tool to retrieve implementation details for a grid or dot-pattern component. This pattern visualization will be used to create a digital guide showing how to properly measure, align, and outline leather or wood pieces before cutting. The pattern serves as a reference for positioning materials according to precise measurements and customer specifications. Once the 2D pattern layout is established, the create_dovetail tool is used to generate a 3D model of the dovetail joint that will be used to join the pieces together. This demonstrates how the complementary pattern layout translates into an actual physical join, allowing the crafter to visualize both the cutting layout and the assembly method.

messages.content: I'm a microbiologist investigating the horizontal gene transfer mechanisms of Extended Spectrum Beta-Lactamase (ESBL) genes in Enterobacteriaceae within hospital wastewater systems. I need to produce a comprehensive technical report for our infection control committee that addresses both the scientific mechanisms and practical implications. The report should include a rigorous analysis of the genetic transfer pathways, hypotheses about environmental factors promoting resistance spread, and evidence from peer-reviewed literature using systematic scientific reasoning. Additionally, I need to incorporate current wastewater treatment protocols, real-world case studies from healthcare facilities, and emerging mitigation strategies, all compiled into a final document with executive summary, data analysis, and visual recommendations. Can you help me prepare this complete report covering both the molecular science and practical environmental management aspects?

confidence.description: P1.5 confidence vector [empirical_support, theoretical_basis, methodological_rigor, consensus_alignment]

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is designed for advanced scientific research, specifically in immunology, dermatology, and computational biology. It employs an 8-stage graph-based methodology to facilitate systematic scientific reasoning, hypothesis generation, evidence integration, and causal inference. The available tools support structured research workflows, bias mitigation, interdisciplinary collaboration, and rigorous statistical analysis. The server's primary focus is on enabling reliable and comprehensive scientific research with features like multi-dimensional confidence tracking and resilience against query failures.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Web Search & Research" is chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around advanced research capabilities, hypothesis generation, and evidence integration, which align with research-oriented tools. The secondary label "Data Analysis & Processing" is included due to the statistical rigor and analytical features described. The secondary label "AI/ML Tools" is considered because the graph-based methodology and hypothesis generation suggest the use of algorithmic intelligence, though it is not explicit. A custom label is added to highlight the unique graph-based scientific reasoning methodology specific to this server.
