tools.name: list_marts
tools.description:
Lists all available Biomart marts (databases) from Ensembl.

    Biomart organizes biological data in a hierarchy: MART -> DATASET -> ATTRIBUTES/FILTERS.
    This function returns all available marts as a CSV string.

    Returns:
        str: CSV-formatted table of all marts with their display names and descriptions.

    Example:
        list_marts()
        >>> "name,display_name,description
             ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL,Ensembl Genes,Gene annotation from Ensembl
             ENSEMBL_MART_MOUSE,Mouse strains,Strain-specific data for mouse
             ..."

tools.name: list_datasets
tools.description:
Lists all available biomart datasets for a given mart.

    Each mart contains multiple datasets. This function returns all datasets
    available in the specified mart as a CSV string.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier to list datasets from.
            Valid values include: ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL, ENSEMBL_MART_MOUSE,
            ENSEMBL_MART_ONTOLOGY, ENSEMBL_MART_GENOMIC, ENSEMBL_MART_SNP,
            ENSEMBL_MART_FUNCGEN

    Returns:
        str: CSV-formatted table of all datasets with their display names and descriptions.

    Example:
        list_datasets("ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        >>> "name,display_name,description
             hsapiens_gene_ensembl,Human genes,Human genes (GRCh38.p13)
             mmusculus_gene_ensembl,Mouse genes,Mouse genes (GRCm39)
             ..."

tools.name: list_common_attributes
tools.description:
Lists commonly used attributes available for a given dataset.

    This function returns only the most frequently used attributes (defined in COMMON_ATTRIBUTES)
    to avoid overwhelming the model with too many options. For a complete list,
    use list_all_attributes.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier (e.g., "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        dataset (str): The dataset identifier (e.g., "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")

    Returns:
        str: CSV-formatted table of common attributes with their display names and descriptions.

    Example:
        list_common_attributes("ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL", "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")
        >>> "name,display_name,description
             ensembl_gene_id,Gene stable ID,Ensembl stable ID for the gene
             external_gene_name,Gene name,The gene name
             ..."

tools.name: list_all_attributes
tools.description:
Lists all available attributes for a given dataset with some filtering.

    This function returns a filtered list of all attributes available for the specified
    dataset. Some less commonly used attributes (homologs, microarray probes) are
    filtered out to reduce the response size.

    CAUTION: This function can return a large number of attributes and may be unstable
    for certain datasets. Consider using list_common_attributes first.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier (e.g., "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        dataset (str): The dataset identifier (e.g., "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")

    Returns:
        str: CSV-formatted table of all filtered attributes.

    Example:
        list_all_attributes("ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL", "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")

tools.name: list_filters
tools.description:
Lists all available filters for a given dataset.

    Filters are used to narrow down the results of a Biomart query.
    This function returns all filters that can be applied to the specified dataset.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier (e.g., "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        dataset (str): The dataset identifier (e.g., "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")

    Returns:
        str: CSV-formatted table of all filters with their display names and descriptions.

    Example:
        list_filters("ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL", "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")
        >>> "name,description
             chromosome_name,Chromosome/scaffold name
             start,Gene start (bp)
             end,Gene end (bp)
             ..."

tools.name: get_data
tools.description:
Queries Biomart for data using specified attributes and filters.

    This function performs the main data retrieval from Biomart, allowing you to
    query biological data by specifying which attributes to return and which filters
    to apply. Includes automatic retry logic for resilience.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier (e.g., "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        dataset (str): The dataset identifier (e.g., "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")
        attributes (list[str]): List of attributes to retrieve (e.g., ["ensembl_gene_id", "external_gene_name"])
        filters (dict[str, str]): Dictionary of filters to apply (e.g., {"chromosome_name": "1"})

    Returns:
        str: CSV-formatted results of the query.

    Example:
        get_data(
            "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL",
            "hsapiens_gene_ensembl",
            ["ensembl_gene_id", "external_gene_name", "chromosome_name"],
            {"chromosome_name": "X", "biotype": "protein_coding"}
        )
        >>> "ensembl_gene_id,external_gene_name,chromosome_name
             ENSG00000000003,TSPAN6,X
             ENSG00000000005,TNMD,X
             ..."

tools.name: get_translation
tools.description:
Translates a single identifier from one attribute type to another.

    This function allows conversion between different identifier types, such as
    converting a gene symbol to an Ensembl ID. Results are cached to improve performance.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier (e.g., "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        dataset (str): The dataset identifier (e.g., "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")
        from_attr (str): The source attribute name (e.g., "hgnc_symbol")
        to_attr (str): The target attribute name (e.g., "ensembl_gene_id")
        target (str): The identifier value to translate (e.g., "TP53")

    Returns:
        str: The translated identifier, or an error message if not found.

    Example:
        get_translation("ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL", "hsapiens_gene_ensembl", "hgnc_symbol", "ensembl_gene_id", "TP53")
        >>> "ENSG00000141510"

tools.name: batch_translate
tools.description:
Translates multiple identifiers in a single batch operation.

    This function is more efficient than multiple calls to get_translation when
    you need to translate many identifiers at once.

    Args:
        mart (str): The mart identifier (e.g., "ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL")
        dataset (str): The dataset identifier (e.g., "hsapiens_gene_ensembl")
        from_attr (str): The source attribute name (e.g., "hgnc_symbol")
        to_attr (str): The target attribute name (e.g., "ensembl_gene_id")
        targets (list[str]): List of identifier values to translate (e.g., ["TP53", "BRCA1", "BRCA2"])

    Returns:
        dict: A dictionary containing:
            - translations: Dictionary mapping input IDs to translated IDs
            - not_found: List of IDs that could not be translated
            - found_count: Number of successfully translated IDs
            - not_found_count: Number of IDs that could not be translated

    Example:
        batch_translate("ENSEMBL_MART_ENSEMBL", "hsapiens_gene_ensembl", "hgnc_symbol", "ensembl_gene_id", ["TP53", "BRCA1", "BRCA2"])
        >>> {"translations": {"TP53": "ENSG00000141510", "BRCA1": "ENSG00000012048"}, "not_found": ["BRCA2"], "found_count": 2, "not_found_count": 1}

labels.analysis: The MCP Server specializes in biological data retrieval and analysis through interactions with Biomart databases. Its primary function is to facilitate the discovery, exploration, and querying of biological data by providing access to various datasets, attributes, and filters within Biomart. The server offers tools for listing available marts and datasets, exploring attributes and filters, and retrieving specific biological data based on user-defined queries. It also supports identifier translation between different attribute types, which is crucial for data integration and analysis in bioinformatics.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Bioinformatics & Genomics" was chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around querying and processing biological data, which is central to bioinformatics and genomics research. The secondary label "Data Analysis & Processing" was selected due to the server's capabilities in filtering, transforming, and retrieving biological data for analytical purposes. The secondary label "Database Operations" was also chosen because the server interfaces with organized biological databases (Biomart) and allows querying structured data.

metadata.question: I'm a bioinformatics scientist establishing a new data analysis pipeline for human genomics research. Before I can start querying genomic information, I need to understand what resources are available through the Ensembl Biomart system and identify which data fields I can retrieve. Could you help me explore this by first showing me all available biological databases (marts) in the system, and then examining what common gene attributes are available for the human gene dataset? This will help me plan my workflow and understand what genomic information I can access for my downstream analysis.
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary roles in exploring Biomart's hierarchical biological data structure. `list_marts` provides a high-level view of all available databases (marts) in the Biomart system, giving researchers an overview of what biological data domains are accessible. Once a relevant mart is identified (such as the Ensembl Genes mart for human genomic data), `list_common_attributes` then allows for deeper exploration by listing the frequently used data attributes available for specific datasets within that mart. The first tool outputs mart identifiers that become necessary input parameters for the second tool, creating a logical discovery workflow from broad database identification to specific attribute exploration.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow follows a natural exploratory pattern for bioinformatics research: (1) First, use `list_marts` to discover all available biological databases/marts and identify the relevant one for the research (typically the Ensembl Genes mart for human genomics); (2) Then, use the mart identifier from step 1 along with a specific dataset identifier (such as "hsapiens_gene_ensembl" for human genes) as inputs to `list_common_attributes` to retrieve the available data fields that can be queried. This two-step process enables researchers to understand both what data sources exist and what specific information they can extract before constructing their actual data queries.

messages.content: I'm preparing a comprehensive proposal for a potential client in the healthcare industry who is considering hiring our firm to conduct a nationwide patient satisfaction survey. I need to set up the data exploration configurations for how we'll visualize and analyze the survey results once we collect them, including metrics for satisfaction scores, demographic breakdowns, and trend analysis. Additionally, I need to generate a detailed research proposal document that includes current industry benchmarks for patient satisfaction surveys, recommended methodology, sample size calculations, and projected timeline to help us win this project. Can you help me configure both the visualization setup and create the comprehensive proposal report?

server_info.name: Superset Integration
server_info.author: @aptro/superset-mcp
server_info.overview: Connect and control your Apache Superset instance programmatically with ease. Enable AI agents to manage dashboards, charts, and databases using natural language requests. Streamline your data exploration and visualization tasks effortlessly.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "supersetBaseUrl": "http://localhost:8088"
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@aptro/superset-mcp/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

tools.name: superset_auth_check_token_validity
tools.description:
Check if the current access token is still valid

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/me/ endpoint to test if the current token is valid.
    Use this to verify authentication status before making other API calls.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with token validity status and any error information

tools.name: superset_auth_refresh_token
tools.description:
Refresh the access token using the refresh endpoint

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/security/refresh endpoint to get a new access token
    without requiring re-authentication with username/password.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the new access token or error information

tools.name: superset_auth_authenticate_user
tools.description:
Authenticate with Superset and get access token

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/security/login endpoint to authenticate and obtain an access token.
    If there's an existing token, will first try to check its validity.
    If invalid, will attempt to refresh token before falling back to re-authentication.

    Args:
        username: Superset username (falls back to environment variable if not provided)
        password: Superset password (falls back to environment variable if not provided)
        refresh: Whether to refresh the token if invalid (defaults to True)

    Returns:
        A dictionary with authentication status and access token or error information

tools.name: superset_dashboard_list
tools.description:
Get a list of dashboards from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/ endpoint to retrieve all dashboards
    the current user has access to view. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing dashboard data including id, title, url, and metadata

tools.name: superset_dashboard_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific dashboard

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific dashboard.

    Args:
        dashboard_id: ID of the dashboard to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete dashboard information including components and layout

tools.name: superset_dashboard_create
tools.description:
Create a new dashboard in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/ POST endpoint to create a new dashboard.

    Args:
        dashboard_title: Title of the dashboard
        json_metadata: Optional JSON metadata for dashboard configuration,
                       can include layout, color scheme, and filter configuration

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created dashboard information including its ID

tools.name: superset_dashboard_update
tools.description:
Update an existing dashboard

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/{id} PUT endpoint to update
    dashboard properties.

    Args:
        dashboard_id: ID of the dashboard to update
        data: Data to update, can include dashboard_title, slug, owners, position, and metadata

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the updated dashboard information

tools.name: superset_dashboard_delete
tools.description:
Delete a dashboard

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a dashboard.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone.

    Args:
        dashboard_id: ID of the dashboard to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_chart_list
tools.description:
Get a list of charts from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/ endpoint to retrieve all charts
    the current user has access to view. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing chart data including id, slice_name, viz_type, and datasource info

tools.name: superset_chart_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific chart

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific chart/slice.

    Args:
        chart_id: ID of the chart to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete chart information including visualization configuration

tools.name: superset_chart_create
tools.description:
Create a new chart in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/ POST endpoint to create a new visualization.

    Args:
        slice_name: Name/title of the chart
        datasource_id: ID of the dataset or SQL table
        datasource_type: Type of datasource ('table' for datasets, 'query' for SQL)
        viz_type: Visualization type (e.g., 'bar', 'line', 'pie', 'big_number', etc.)
        params: Visualization parameters including metrics, groupby, time_range, etc.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created chart information including its ID

tools.name: superset_chart_update
tools.description:
Update an existing chart

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/{id} PUT endpoint to update
    chart properties and visualization settings.

    Args:
        chart_id: ID of the chart to update
        data: Data to update, can include slice_name, description, viz_type, params, etc.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the updated chart information

tools.name: superset_chart_delete
tools.description:
Delete a chart

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a chart.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone.

    Args:
        chart_id: ID of the chart to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_database_list
tools.description:
Get a list of databases from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/ endpoint to retrieve all database
    connections the current user has access to. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing database connection information including id, name, and configuration

tools.name: superset_database_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific database connection.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete database configuration information

tools.name: superset_database_create
tools.description:
Create a new database connection in Superset

    IMPORTANT: Don't call this tool, unless user have given connection details. This function will only create database connections with explicit user consent and input.
    No default values or assumptions will be made without user confirmation. All connection parameters,
    including sensitive credentials, must be explicitly provided by the user.

    Makes a POST request to /api/v1/database/ to create a new database connection in Superset.
    The endpoint requires a valid SQLAlchemy URI and database configuration parameters.
    The engine parameter will be automatically determined from the SQLAlchemy URI prefix if not specified:
    - 'postgresql://' -> engine='postgresql'
    - 'mysql://' -> engine='mysql'
    - 'mssql://' -> engine='mssql'
    - 'oracle://' -> engine='oracle'
    - 'sqlite://' -> engine='sqlite'

    The SQLAlchemy URI must follow the format: dialect+driver://username:password@host:port/database
    If the URI is not provided, the function will prompt for individual connection parameters to construct it.

    All required parameters must be provided and validated before creating the connection.
    The configuration_method parameter should typically be set to 'sqlalchemy_form'.

    Args:
        engine: Database engine (e.g., 'postgresql', 'mysql', etc.)
        configuration_method: Method used for configuration (typically 'sqlalchemy_form')
        database_name: Name for the database connection
        sqlalchemy_uri: SQLAlchemy URI for the connection (e.g., 'postgresql://user:pass@host/db')

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created database connection information including its ID

tools.name: superset_database_get_tables
tools.description:
Get a list of tables for a given database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/tables/ endpoint to retrieve
    all tables available in the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of tables including schema and table name information

tools.name: superset_database_schemas
tools.description:
Get schemas for a specific database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/schemas/ endpoint to retrieve
    all schemas available in the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of schema names

tools.name: superset_database_test_connection
tools.description:
Test a database connection

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/test_connection endpoint to verify if
    the provided connection details can successfully connect to the database.

    Args:
        database_data: Database connection details including sqlalchemy_uri and other parameters

    Returns:
        A dictionary with connection test results

tools.name: superset_database_update
tools.description:
Update an existing database connection

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id} PUT endpoint to update
    database connection properties.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to update
        data: Data to update, can include database_name, sqlalchemy_uri, password, and extra configs

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the updated database information

tools.name: superset_database_delete
tools.description:
Delete a database connection

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a database connection.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone. This will also remove associated datasets.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_database_get_catalogs
tools.description:
Get all catalogs from a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/catalogs/ endpoint to retrieve
    all catalogs available in the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of catalog names for databases that support catalogs

tools.name: superset_database_get_connection
tools.description:
Get database connection information

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/connection endpoint to retrieve
    connection details for a specific database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with detailed connection information

tools.name: superset_database_get_function_names
tools.description:
Get function names supported by a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/function_names/ endpoint to retrieve
    all SQL functions supported by the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of supported function names

tools.name: superset_database_get_related_objects
tools.description:
Get charts and dashboards associated with a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/related_objects/ endpoint to retrieve
    counts and references of charts and dashboards that depend on this database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with counts and lists of related charts and dashboards

tools.name: superset_database_validate_sql
tools.description:
Validate arbitrary SQL against a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/validate_sql/ endpoint to check
    if the provided SQL is valid for the specified database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database
        sql: SQL query to validate

    Returns:
        A dictionary with validation results

tools.name: superset_database_validate_parameters
tools.description:
Validate database connection parameters

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/validate_parameters/ endpoint to verify
    if the provided connection parameters are valid without creating a connection.

    Args:
        parameters: Connection parameters to validate

    Returns:
        A dictionary with validation results

tools.name: superset_dataset_list
tools.description:
Get a list of datasets from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dataset/ endpoint to retrieve all datasets
    the current user has access to view. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing dataset information including id, table_name, and database

tools.name: superset_dataset_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific dataset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dataset/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific dataset including columns and metrics.

    Args:
        dataset_id: ID of the dataset to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete dataset information

tools.name: superset_dataset_create
tools.description:
Create a new dataset in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dataset/ POST endpoint to create a new dataset
    from an existing database table or view.

    Args:
        table_name: Name of the physical table in the database
        database_id: ID of the database where the table exists
        schema: Optional database schema name where the table is located
        owners: Optional list of user IDs who should own this dataset

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created dataset information including its ID

tools.name: superset_sqllab_execute_query
tools.description:
Execute a SQL query in SQL Lab

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/execute/ endpoint to run a SQL query
    against the specified database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to query
        sql: SQL query to execute

    Returns:
        A dictionary with query results or execution status for async queries

tools.name: superset_sqllab_get_saved_queries
tools.description:
Get a list of saved queries from SQL Lab

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/saved_query/ endpoint to retrieve all saved queries
    the current user has access to. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing saved query information including id, label, and database

tools.name: superset_sqllab_format_sql
tools.description:
Format a SQL query for better readability

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/format_sql endpoint to apply standard
    formatting rules to the provided SQL query.

    Args:
        sql: SQL query to format

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the formatted SQL

tools.name: superset_sqllab_get_results
tools.description:
Get results of a previously executed SQL query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/results/ endpoint to retrieve results
    for an asynchronous query using its result key.

    Args:
        key: Result key to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with query results including column information and data rows

tools.name: superset_sqllab_estimate_query_cost
tools.description:
Estimate the cost of executing a SQL query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/estimate endpoint to get approximate cost
    information for a query before executing it.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database
        sql: SQL query to estimate
        schema: Optional schema name

    Returns:
        A dictionary with estimated query cost metrics

tools.name: superset_sqllab_export_query_results
tools.description:
Export the results of a SQL query to CSV

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/export/{client_id} endpoint to download
    query results in CSV format.

    Args:
        client_id: Client ID of the query

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the exported data or error information

tools.name: superset_sqllab_get_bootstrap_data
tools.description:
Get the bootstrap data for SQL Lab

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/ endpoint to retrieve configuration data
    needed for the SQL Lab interface.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with SQL Lab configuration including allowed databases and settings

tools.name: superset_saved_query_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific saved query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/saved_query/{id} endpoint to retrieve information
    about a saved SQL query.

    Args:
        query_id: ID of the saved query to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the saved query details including SQL text and database

tools.name: superset_saved_query_create
tools.description:
Create a new saved query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/saved_query/ POST endpoint to save a SQL query
    for later reuse.

    Args:
        query_data: Dictionary containing the query information including:
                   - db_id: Database ID
                   - schema: Schema name (optional)
                   - sql: SQL query text
                   - label: Display name for the saved query
                   - description: Optional description of the query

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created saved query information including its ID

tools.name: superset_query_stop
tools.description:
Stop a running query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/query/stop endpoint to terminate a query that
    is currently running.

    Args:
        client_id: Client ID of the query to stop

    Returns:
        A dictionary with confirmation of query termination

tools.name: superset_query_list
tools.description:
Get a list of queries from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/query/ endpoint to retrieve query history.
    Results are paginated and include both finished and running queries.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing query information including status, duration, and SQL

tools.name: superset_query_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/query/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific query execution.

    Args:
        query_id: ID of the query to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete query execution information

tools.name: superset_activity_get_recent
tools.description:
Get recent activity data for the current user

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/log/recent_activity/ endpoint to retrieve
    a history of actions performed by the current user.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with recent user activities including viewed charts and dashboards

tools.name: superset_user_get_current
tools.description:
Get information about the currently authenticated user

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/me/ endpoint to retrieve the user's profile
    information including permissions and preferences.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with user profile data

tools.name: superset_user_get_roles
tools.description:
Get roles for the current user

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/me/roles/ endpoint to retrieve all roles
    assigned to the current user.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with user role information

tools.name: superset_tag_list
tools.description:
Get a list of tags from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/ endpoint to retrieve all tags
    defined in the Superset instance.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing tag information including id and name

tools.name: superset_tag_create
tools.description:
Create a new tag in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/ POST endpoint to create a new tag
    that can be applied to objects like charts and dashboards.

    Args:
        name: Name for the tag

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created tag information

tools.name: superset_tag_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific tag

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/{id} endpoint to retrieve information
    about a specific tag.

    Args:
        tag_id: ID of the tag to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with tag details

tools.name: superset_tag_objects
tools.description:
Get objects associated with tags

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/get_objects/ endpoint to retrieve
    all objects that have tags assigned to them.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with tagged objects grouped by tag

tools.name: superset_tag_delete
tools.description:
Delete a tag

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a tag.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone.

    Args:
        tag_id: ID of the tag to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_tag_object_add
tools.description:
Add a tag to an object

    Makes a request to tag an object with a specific tag. This creates an association
    between the tag and the specified object (chart, dashboard, etc.)

    Args:
        object_type: Type of the object ('chart', 'dashboard', etc.)
        object_id: ID of the object to tag
        tag_name: Name of the tag to apply

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the tagging confirmation

tools.name: superset_tag_object_remove
tools.description:
Remove a tag from an object

    Makes a request to remove a tag association from a specific object.

    Args:
        object_type: Type of the object ('chart', 'dashboard', etc.)
        object_id: ID of the object to untag
        tag_name: Name of the tag to remove

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the untagging confirmation message

tools.name: superset_explore_form_data_create
tools.description:
Create form data for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/form_data POST endpoint to store
    chart configuration data temporarily.

    Args:
        form_data: Chart configuration including datasource, metrics, and visualization settings

    Returns:
        A dictionary with a key that can be used to retrieve the form data

tools.name: superset_explore_form_data_get
tools.description:
Get form data for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/form_data/{key} endpoint to retrieve
    previously stored chart configuration.

    Args:
        key: Key of the form data to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the stored chart configuration

tools.name: superset_explore_permalink_create
tools.description:
Create a permalink for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/permalink POST endpoint to generate
    a shareable link to a specific chart exploration state.

    Args:
        state: State data for the permalink including form_data

    Returns:
        A dictionary with a key that can be used to access the permalink

tools.name: superset_explore_permalink_get
tools.description:
Get a permalink for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/permalink/{key} endpoint to retrieve
    a previously saved exploration state.

    Args:
        key: Key of the permalink to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the stored exploration state

tools.name: superset_menu_get
tools.description:
Get the Superset menu data

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/menu/ endpoint to retrieve the navigation
    menu structure based on user permissions.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with menu items and their configurations

tools.name: superset_config_get_base_url
tools.description:
Get the base URL of the Superset instance

    Returns the configured Superset base URL that this MCP server is connecting to.
    This can be useful for constructing full URLs to Superset resources or for
    displaying information about the connected instance.

    This tool does not require authentication as it only returns configuration information.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the Superset base URL

tools.name: superset_advanced_data_type_convert
tools.description:
Convert a value to an advanced data type

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/advanced_data_type/convert endpoint to transform
    a value into the specified advanced data type format.

    Args:
        type_name: Name of the advanced data type
        value: Value to convert

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the converted value

tools.name: superset_advanced_data_type_list
tools.description:
Get list of available advanced data types

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/advanced_data_type/types endpoint to retrieve
    all advanced data types supported by this Superset instance.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with available advanced data types and their configurations

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is focused on integrating with and controlling Apache Superset, a popular open-source data visualization platform. It provides a comprehensive suite of tools to programmatically interact with Superset's core functionalities including dashboard management, chart creation and modification, database operations (listing, creating, updating, deleting), SQL query execution and management, data exploration configuration, authentication handling, and user management. The server enables AI agents to handle these operations via natural language requests, streamlining data exploration and visualization workflows.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality is focused on data visualization and management through Superset integration. The secondary categories reflect the server's additional capabilities in database operations and SQL query processing. The custom label highlights the unique aspect of enabling AI agents to control Superset programmatically.

server_info.name: DeepResearch
server_info.author: @ameeralns/DeepResearchMCP
server_info.overview: Conduct intelligent, iterative research on any topic with automated web searches and comprehensive report generation. Generate detailed reports that include executive summaries, analyses, and visualizations, all while managing content efficiently. Enhance your research capabilities with structured knowledge processing and error resilience features.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@ameeralns/DeepResearchMCP/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client

metadata.question: I'm preparing a comprehensive proposal for a potential client in the healthcare industry who is considering hiring our firm to conduct a nationwide patient satisfaction survey. I need to set up the data exploration configurations for how we'll visualize and analyze the survey results once we collect them, including metrics for satisfaction scores, demographic breakdowns, and trend analysis. Additionally, I need to generate a detailed research proposal document that includes current industry benchmarks for patient satisfaction surveys, recommended methodology, sample size calculations, and projected timeline to help us win this project. Can you help me configure both the visualization setup and create the comprehensive proposal report?
metadata.tool_analysis: The Superset Integration tool (superset_explore_form_data_create) specialize in creating chart configuration data for visualization and data exploration, which aligns with preparing survey data summaries and analyses. The DeepResearch tool (generate-report) focuses on comprehensive report generation including executive summaries and analyses, which supports writing proposals. Together, these tools enable a Survey Researcher to prepare technical data visualization configurations while simultaneously generating comprehensive research proposals. The workflow involves setting up analytical frameworks for existing survey data and creating detailed proposals for new business opportunities.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with using the Superset tool to create form data configurations that define how survey data will be explored and visualized. This establishes the analytical foundation for presenting survey findings. Then, the DeepResearch tool is used to generate a comprehensive proposal report that synthesizes market research, methodology recommendations, and strategic insights. The two tools work complementarily - one prepares the technical infrastructure for data analysis and presentation, while the other creates the persuasive narrative and research synthesis needed to win new projects.

messages.content: I'm a curator at a European cultural heritage museum preparing for our upcoming outreach initiatives. I need to find relevant academic conferences focused on Renaissance art and cultural heritage where I could potentially present our institution's research and network with other professionals. Additionally, I need to gather comprehensive information about one of our significant Renaissance paintings (artwork ID: EH-2489) in our collection, including its provenance, authentication details, and historical context, so I can prepare presentation materials and assess its cultural significance for potential discussions at these events. Can you help me identify suitable upcoming conferences and retrieve the detailed information I need about this artwork?

metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools complement each other in a curatorial workflow where a museum professional needs to both research their institution's holdings and find appropriate opportunities to share that knowledge externally. The `get_events` tool helps identify academic conferences and events where curators can promote their institution's services and maintain professional alliances. This enables the curator to both find opportunities to promote their institution and prepare the knowledge necessary to make effective presentations.

tools.name: list_projects
tools.description: Find and list all KiCad projects on this system.

tools.name: get_project_structure
tools.description: Get the structure and files of a KiCad project.

tools.name: open_project
tools.description: Open a KiCad project in KiCad.

tools.name: validate_project
tools.description: Basic validation of a KiCad project.

tools.name: generate_pcb_thumbnail
tools.description:
Generate a thumbnail image of a KiCad PCB layout using kicad-cli.

        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            ctx: Context for MCP communication

        Returns:
            Thumbnail image of the PCB or None if generation failed

tools.name: generate_project_thumbnail
tools.description: Generate a thumbnail of a KiCad project's PCB layout (Alias for generate_pcb_thumbnail).

tools.name: get_drc_history_tool
tools.description:
Get the DRC check history for a KiCad project.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with DRC history entries

tools.name: run_drc_check
tools.description:
Run a Design Rule Check on a KiCad PCB file.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with DRC results and statistics

tools.name: analyze_bom
tools.description:
Analyze a KiCad project's Bill of Materials.
        
        This tool will look for BOM files related to a KiCad project and provide
        analysis including component counts, categories, and cost estimates if available.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with BOM analysis results

tools.name: export_bom_csv
tools.description:
Export a Bill of Materials for a KiCad project.
        
        This tool attempts to generate a CSV BOM file for a KiCad project.
        It requires KiCad to be installed with the appropriate command-line tools.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with export results

tools.name: extract_schematic_netlist
tools.description:
Extract netlist information from a KiCad schematic.
        
        This tool parses a KiCad schematic file and extracts comprehensive
        netlist information including components, connections, and labels.
        
        Args:
            schematic_path: Path to the KiCad schematic file (.kicad_sch)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with netlist information

tools.name: extract_project_netlist
tools.description:
Extract netlist from a KiCad project's schematic.
        
        This tool finds the schematic associated with a KiCad project
        and extracts its netlist information.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with netlist information

tools.name: analyze_schematic_connections
tools.description:
Analyze connections in a KiCad schematic.
        
        This tool provides detailed analysis of component connections,
        including power nets, signal paths, and potential issues.
        
        Args:
            schematic_path: Path to the KiCad schematic file (.kicad_sch)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with connection analysis

tools.name: find_component_connections
tools.description:
Find all connections for a specific component in a KiCad project.
        
        This tool extracts information about how a specific component
        is connected to other components in the schematic.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            component_ref: Component reference (e.g., "R1", "U3")
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with component connection information

tools.name: identify_circuit_patterns
tools.description:
Identify common circuit patterns in a KiCad schematic.
        
        This tool analyzes a schematic to recognize common circuit blocks such as:
        - Power supply circuits (linear regulators, switching converters)
        - Amplifier circuits (op-amps, transistor amplifiers)
        - Filter circuits (RC, LC, active filters)
        - Digital interfaces (I2C, SPI, UART)
        - Microcontroller circuits
        - And more
        
        Args:
            schematic_path: Path to the KiCad schematic file (.kicad_sch)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with identified circuit patterns

tools.name: analyze_project_circuit_patterns
tools.description:
Identify circuit patterns in a KiCad project's schematic.
        
        Args:
            project_path: Path to the KiCad project file (.kicad_pro)
            ctx: MCP context for progress reporting
            
        Returns:
            Dictionary with identified circuit patterns

labels.analysis: The KiCad MCP Server is designed to enhance the workflow for PCB design using the KiCad software suite. It provides tools for project management, schematic analysis, and PCB layout verification. Key functionalities include listing and validating projects, generating visual thumbnails, running design rule checks (DRC), analyzing bill of materials (BOM), extracting netlists, and identifying common circuit patterns. The server appears to act as an intermediary that automates and streamlines various aspects of the PCB design process, making it particularly useful for electronic engineers and hardware developers.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Electrical Engineering Tools" was chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around PCB design, schematic analysis, and hardware-related tasks. This is not covered by the predefined categories, hence the creation of a custom label. Secondary labels like "File Management" and "Data Analysis & Processing" were added because the tools handle project files and perform analysis on schematic and BOM data. No predefined secondary labels were a perfect fit, but these came closest to representing additional aspects of the server's functionality.

metadata.question: I'm in the process of building a sturdy test jig for our prototype altimeter circuit. First, I need to bring up the project files to double-check the board dimensions and connector placements. After I have those specs verified, I need to draft the frame for the wooden jig in 3D, specifically applying mortise and tenon joinery to the corners to ensure the structure doesn't vibrate apart during testing.
metadata.tool_analysis: These two tools complement each other by bridging the gap between electronic circuit design and physical prototyping hardware. The KiCad tool provides access to the critical schematics and PCB layout files necessary to understand the electronic component's dimensions and interface requirements. The SketchUp tool then facilitates the design of the physical enclosure or test aid, specifically allowing for the creation of structural joints (mortise and tenon) required to fabricate a durable housing for the electronics. This workflow is essential for an Avionics Technician who needs to transition from a circuit model to a physical test apparatus.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow requires following a design-to-fabrication process. First, the user must open the KiCad project to review the circuit board's layout and confirm physical specifications. Once the constraints of the electronic unit are understood, the user must transition to 3D modeling to construct the physical test fixture. In this modeling phase, a mortise and tenon joint must be created to assemble the frame of the fixture, ensuring it is robust enough for testing the avionics system.

messages.content: I'm working on a custom equipment assembly where two structural support rails need to be connected with a dovetail joint. Before I can create the joint, I need to run a Ruby script to measure both components automatically, calculate the proper tail and pin dimensions based on the rail thickness (which varies), and ensure the components are aligned correctly at a 45-degree angle. Once I have those calculations and the rails are properly positioned, I need to generate the dovetail connection between them. Can you help me set up this complete workflow with the preparation calculations and joint creation?

metadata.question: I'm working on a custom equipment assembly where two structural support rails need to be connected with a dovetail joint. Before I can create the joint, I need to run a Ruby script to measure both components automatically, calculate the proper tail and pin dimensions based on the rail thickness (which varies), and ensure the components are aligned correctly at a 45-degree angle. Once I have those calculations and the rails are properly positioned, I need to generate the dovetail connection between them. Can you help me set up this complete workflow with the preparation calculations and joint creation?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools from the Sketchup Integration server work together to accomplish a complex fabrication workflow. The `eval_ruby` tool enables custom Ruby code execution, which can be used for precise calculations, measurement queries, component positioning, and preparation tasks that require custom logic. The `create_dovetail` tool specializes in creating dovetail joints between components, which is a strong joinery method often used in structural assemblies. These tools complement each other by allowing the user to first prepare and calculate the necessary parameters through Ruby code, then apply those calculations to create a precise dovetail joint between components. This workflow mirrors real-world fabrication processes where preparatory calculations and measurements must precede actual join creation.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with using `eval_ruby` to perform preparatory tasks such as querying component dimensions, calculating optimal joint parameters (based on material thickness, component sizes, and engineering requirements), and ensuring components are properly positioned relative to each other. The calculated parameters (such as tail width, pin spacing, and depth) are then used to inform the `create_dovetail` function, which creates the actual dovetail joint between the two prepared components. The Ruby calculations ensure the joint is precisely engineered for the specific application, while the dovetail creation tool executes the physical joinery operation in the 3D model.

messages.content: I am currently reviewing our executive compensation strategy to ensure we remain competitive in the market. I need to prepare a report that compares our CEO's current pay package against industry standards to justify potential adjustments to the Board. Could you retrieve the industry average compensation benchmarks for the consumer electronics sector, and then pull the detailed compensation data for Apple's (AAPL) top executives so I can perform a side-by-side gap analysis?

server_info.name: Financial Modeling Prep (FMP) Server
server_info.author: @imbenrabi/financial-modeling-prep-mcp-server
server_info.overview: Provide AI assistants with comprehensive access to financial data, stock information, company fundamentals, and market insights. Enable seamless querying and analysis of financial metrics, market indexes, news, and more through a standardized protocol. Empower financial decision-making with real-time and historical data integration. NOTE: some tools require paid API key, see https://site.financialmodelingprep.com/developer/docs for more info.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@imbenrabi/financial-modeling-prep-mcp-server/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

metadata.target_tools: Financial Modeling Prep (FMP) Server::getExecutiveCompensationBenchmark, Financial Modeling Prep (FMP) Server::getExecutiveCompensation
metadata.question: I am currently reviewing our executive compensation strategy to ensure we remain competitive in the market. I need to prepare a report that compares our CEO's current pay package against industry standards to justify potential adjustments to the Board. Could you retrieve the industry average compensation benchmarks for the consumer electronics sector, and then pull the detailed compensation data for Apple's (AAPL) top executives so I can perform a side-by-side gap analysis?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary functions in the executive compensation analysis workflow. The first tool (`getExecutiveCompensation`) provides granular, firm-specific data regarding salaries, stock awards, and total compensation for individual executives. The second tool (`getExecutiveCompensationBenchmark`) provides macro-level data, offering average compensation figures across various industries. Together, they enable a Compensation and Benefits Manager to perform a competitive gap analysis by comparing a specific company's executive pay structure against industry norms, a critical step in developing fair and competitive compensation plans.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by establishing a baseline for market standards using the benchmark tool to retrieve industry average compensation data. This provides the context for what is considered competitive pay. Next, the specific compensation tool is used to retrieve the detailed compensation package for the specific company's executives. Finally, the user compares the specific executive data against the industry benchmarks to identify over- or under-compensation and make informed recommendations.

messages.content: I've been tasked with conducting a comprehensive security assessment for an organization's external infrastructure. Our team follows a two-phase methodology: first, I need to perform open-source intelligence gathering to map out their network footprint and identify all exposed services and hosts associated with their domain. Second, using the intelligence I've gathered, I need to conduct an active penetration test to discover any exploitable vulnerabilities on the discovered targets. The target assessment scope is acme.com. Can you help me complete both phases of this security assessment?

server_info.name: OSINT Server
server_info.author: @himanshusanecha/mcp-osint-server
server_info.overview: Leverage powerful open-source intelligence tools to gather and analyze data from various sources. Enhance your investigations with automated data retrieval and processing capabilities. Simplify your research workflow and make informed decisions faster.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@himanshusanecha/mcp-osint-server/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

labels.analysis: The Pentest MCP Server is designed to integrate essential penetration testing (pentesting) tools into a unified natural language interface. It allows users to execute, chain, and analyze multiple security tools through conversational commands, enhancing efficiency and effectiveness in security assessments. The available tools (nmapScan, generateWordlist, runJohnTheRipper, gobuster, nikto, etc.) are all focused on attacking, scanning, and analyzing systems for vulnerabilities. The server serves as a command-and-control hub for automated pentesting workflows.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality of this server is clearly centered around cybersecurity assessments, specifically penetration testing. The predefined category "Security & Authentication" is the most fitting as it encompasses tools and processes related to system security and vulnerability analysis. Given the automation and workflow integration capabilities, a secondary label of "Development Tools" is added due to its utility in scripting, chaining commands, and potentially debugging phases of pentesting. The custom label "Ethical Hacking Automation" is included to highlight the unique aspect of unifying pentesting tools under a natural language interface for seamless security assessments.

metadata.question: I've been tasked with conducting a comprehensive security assessment for an organization's external infrastructure. Our team follows a two-phase methodology: first, I need to perform open-source intelligence gathering to map out their network footprint and identify all exposed services and hosts associated with their domain. Second, using the intelligence I've gathered, I need to conduct an active penetration test to discover any exploitable vulnerabilities on the discovered targets. The target assessment scope is acme.com. Can you help me complete both phases of this security assessment?
metadata.tool_analysis: Both nmap_scan (OSINT Server) and nmapScan (Pentest MCP) are network scanning tools powered by NMAP, but they serve complementary purposes in a security assessment workflow. The OSINT Server's nmap_scan focuses on gathering intelligence and performing reconnaissance from an open-source intelligence perspective, making it ideal for the initial discovery phase of identifying exposed hosts and services. The Pentest MCP's nmapScan is integrated into a penetration testing framework, designed for active security testing and vulnerability identification as part of an attack chain. Together, they enable a complete security assessment: first performing passive OSINT-based discovery to map the attack surface, then conducting active penetration testing scans to identify exploitable vulnerabilities.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with the OSINT-based scan using nmap_scan to gather intelligence about the target network, identifying all publicly accessible hosts, services, and potential entry points through passive reconnaissance. The results from this initial scan (such as discovered IPs and open ports) inform the second phase, where nmapScan from Pentest MCP performs active, aggressive penetration testing scans on the identified targets. This active scan conducts deeper vulnerability detection and analysis that would alert security systems if used prematurely. The two tools create a logical progression from intelligence gathering to active exploitation testing.

Can you help me create both types of joints between the appropriate components in my model?

metadata.question: I'm designing a wooden bedside table with drawers in 3D modeling software and need to apply appropriate woodworking joinery throughout the piece. For the main table frame that connects the four legs to the horizontal aprons, I need to use a strong traditional joint commonly used in frame furniture construction. Then for constructing the drawer boxes that will hold the sides, front, back, and bottom together, I need to apply a different type of interlocking joint that provides excellent mechanical strength for box corners. Can you help me create both types of joints between the appropriate components in my model?
metadata.tool_analysis: Both tools are woodworking joint creation functions from the Sketchup Integration server. The `create_mortise_tenon` tool creates a traditional mortise and tenon joint, which is commonly used for frame-to-frame connections in furniture construction, such as attaching table legs to aprons or connecting stiles to rails in cabinet frames. The `create_dovetail` tool creates a dovetail joint, which is primarily used for box construction and drawer assembly, providing excellent mechanical interlocking for corners. These two tools complement each other in furniture design projects where both structural frame joinery and box/drawer construction are required. Together, they allow a designer to create a complete piece of furniture with appropriate joints for different structural purposes.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with designing a furniture piece (such as a table with drawers or a cabinet) that requires both structural frame connections and box/drawer construction. First, the user would identify the frame components needing strong structural connections (like legs connecting to aprons or stiles connecting to rails) and use the mortise and tenon joint creation tool for these connections. Second, the user would identify the box construction areas (like drawer boxes or cabinet carcass corners) and use the dovetail joint creation tool for these connections. The two tools work together to create a complete furniture assembly with appropriate joinery techniques applied to different parts based on their structural requirements.

messages.content: I am a Natural Sciences Manager overseeing the modernization of our marine biology research unit's data collection methods. We are transitioning from manual logging to an automated environmental monitoring system, and I need to present a thorough feasibility study to the board next week. First, I need to deconstruct our current operations to understand the complex interactions and dependencies between our field equipment, on-site data entry staff, and legacy databases, specifically looking for points of friction that could cause the system to fail during the transition. Once we have mapped out these systemic risks, I need you to research industry best practices for similar scientific instrumentation upgrades and compile a detailed report that includes an executive summary, an analysis of the identified risks within the system context, and a phased implementation proposal.

The `generate-report` tool from the DeepResearch server complements this by taking the identified structural needs and risks, conducting external research on best practices and industry standards, and synthesizing both the internal analysis and external data into a formal, stakeholder-ready feasibility document.

messages.content: I'm preparing a quarterly sales analysis report for our executive management meeting next week and need to set up the complete visualization system. I've developed a configuration for a complex multi-series line chart that will display sales performance across our four regional markets over the past 12 months. The chart configuration breaks down sales by product category and includes trend markers for each region. My dataset contains the following columns: date, region, sales_amount, product_category, and sales_rep. Before I commit to the full dashboard setup, I need to validate that my chart configuration is correctly structured and will render properly with my data. After I confirm the visualization is valid, I need to create a new dashboard in our business intelligence platform titled "Q4 2024 Regional Sales Performance Dashboard" with a default grid layout and pre-configured filtering options for the four regions. The dashboard should include metadata specifying a dark color scheme optimized for projector presentations during the meeting. Can you first validate my chart configuration to ensure everything is working correctly, and then proceed to create the dashboard container? Please return the dashboard ID after creation so I can track it in our project documentation system.
