        - tips: contains mix of numerical and categorical columns, good for bar, pie, etc.
        - stocks: stock prices, good for line, scatter, generally things that change over time
        - gapminder: demographic data, good for line, scatter, generally things with maps or many categories

    Args:
        data_name: Name of the dataset to get sample data for

    Returns:
        Data info object containing information about the dataset.

tools.name: validate_model_config
tools.description:
Validate Vizro model configuration. Run ALWAYS when you have a complete dashboard configuration.

    If successful, the tool will return the python code and, if it is a remote file, the py.cafe link to the chart.
    The PyCafe link will be automatically opened in your default browser if auto_open is True.

    Args:
        dashboard_config: Either a JSON string or a dictionary representing a Vizro dashboard model configuration
        data_infos: List of DFMetaData objects containing information about the data files
        auto_open: Whether to automatically open the PyCafe link in a browser

    Returns:
        ValidationResults object with status and dashboard details

tools.name: get_model_json_schema
tools.description:
Get the JSON schema for the specified Vizro model.

    Args:
        model_name: Name of the Vizro model to get schema for (e.g., 'Card', 'Dashboard', 'Page')

    Returns:
        JSON schema of the requested Vizro model

tools.name: get_vizro_chart_or_dashboard_plan
tools.description: Get instructions for creating a Vizro chart or dashboard. Call FIRST when asked to create Vizro things.

tools.name: load_and_analyze_data
tools.description:
Load data from various file formats into a pandas DataFrame and analyze its structure.

    Supported formats:
    - CSV (.csv)
    - JSON (.json)
    - HTML (.html, .htm)
    - Excel (.xls, .xlsx)
    - OpenDocument Spreadsheet (.ods)
    - Parquet (.parquet)

    Args:
        path_or_url: Local file path or URL to a data file

    Returns:
        DataAnalysisResults object containing DataFrame information and metadata

tools.name: validate_chart_code
tools.description:
Validate the chart code created by the user and optionally open the PyCafe link in a browser.

    Args:
        chart_config: A ChartPlan object with the chart configuration
        data_info: Metadata for the dataset to be used in the chart
        auto_open: Whether to automatically open the PyCafe link in a browser

    Returns:
        ValidationResults object with status and dashboard details

ChartPlan.description: Base chart plan used to generate chart code based on user visualization requirements.

chart_type.description: Describes the chart type that best reflects the user request.
chart_type.title: Chart Type

imports.description:
List of import statements required to render the chart defined by the `chart_code` field. Ensure that every
        import statement is a separate list/array entry: An example of valid list of import statements would be:

        ["import pandas as pd",
        "import plotly.express as px"]
imports.title: Imports

chart_code.description:
Python code that generates a generates a plotly go.Figure object. It must fulfill the following criteria:
        1. Must be wrapped in a function name
        2. Must accept a single argument `data_frame` which is a pandas DataFrame
        3. Must return a plotly go.Figure object
        4. All data used in the chart must be derived from the data_frame argument, all data manipulations
        must be done within the function.
chart_code.title: Chart Code

ChartPlan.title: ChartPlan

labels.analysis: The MCP Server "Vizro" is primarily focused on data visualization and dashboard creation using a low-code Python toolkit. Its core functionality revolves around enabling users to quickly build, customize, and deploy interactive data visualization applications with minimal technical expertise. The available tools support the entire workflow, from data loading and analysis to chart creation, validation, and deployment. Vizro emphasizes rapid prototyping and scalable deployment, with built-in design best practices and flexible dependencies.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Data Analysis & Processing" is chosen because the server's main functionality centers around processing and visualizing data. Secondary labels "Development Tools" and "AI/ML Tools" are added because of the server's Python-based low-code approach and potential integration with machine learning models for enhanced visualization. No custom label is needed as the functionality is well-covered by the predefined categories.

server_info.name: Superset Integration
server_info.author: @aptro/superset-mcp
server_info.overview: Connect and control your Apache Superset instance programmatically with ease. Enable AI agents to manage dashboards, charts, and databases using natural language requests. Streamline your data exploration and visualization tasks effortlessly.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "supersetBaseUrl": "http://localhost:8088"
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@aptro/superset-mcp/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

tools.name: superset_auth_check_token_validity
tools.description:
Check if the current access token is still valid

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/me/ endpoint to test if the current token is valid.
    Use this to verify authentication status before making other API calls.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with token validity status and any error information

tools.name: superset_auth_refresh_token
tools.description:
Refresh the access token using the refresh endpoint

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/security/refresh endpoint to get a new access token
    without requiring re-authentication with username/password.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the new access token or error information

tools.name: superset_auth_authenticate_user
tools.description:
Authenticate with Superset and get access token

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/security/login endpoint to authenticate and obtain an access token.
    If there's an existing token, will first try to check its validity.
    If invalid, will attempt to refresh token before falling back to re-authentication.

    Args:
        username: Superset username (falls back to environment variable if not provided)
        password: Superset password (falls back to environment variable if not provided)
        refresh: Whether to refresh the token if invalid (defaults to True)

    Returns:
        A dictionary with authentication status and access token or error information

tools.name: superset_dashboard_list
tools.description:
Get a list of dashboards from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/ endpoint to retrieve all dashboards
    the current user has access to view. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing dashboard data including id, title, url, and metadata

tools.name: superset_dashboard_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific dashboard

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific dashboard.

    Args:
        dashboard_id: ID of the dashboard to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete dashboard information including components and layout

tools.name: superset_dashboard_create
tools.description:
Create a new dashboard in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/ POST endpoint to create a new dashboard.

    Args:
        dashboard_title: Title of the dashboard
        json_metadata: Optional JSON metadata for dashboard configuration,
                       can include layout, color scheme, and filter configuration

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created dashboard information including its ID

tools.name: superset_dashboard_update
tools.description:
Update an existing dashboard

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/{id} PUT endpoint to update
    dashboard properties.

    Args:
        dashboard_id: ID of the dashboard to update
        data: Data to update, can include dashboard_title, slug, owners, position, and metadata

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the updated dashboard information

tools.name: superset_dashboard_delete
tools.description:
Delete a dashboard

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dashboard/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a dashboard.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone.

    Args:
        dashboard_id: ID of the dashboard to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_chart_list
tools.description:
Get a list of charts from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/ endpoint to retrieve all charts
    the current user has access to view. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing chart data including id, slice_name, viz_type, and datasource info

tools.name: superset_chart_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific chart

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific chart/slice.

    Args:
        chart_id: ID of the chart to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete chart information including visualization configuration

tools.name: superset_chart_create
tools.description:
Create a new chart in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/ POST endpoint to create a new visualization.

    Args:
        slice_name: Name/title of the chart
        datasource_id: ID of the dataset or SQL table
        datasource_type: Type of datasource ('table' for datasets, 'query' for SQL)
        viz_type: Visualization type (e.g., 'bar', 'line', 'pie', 'big_number', etc.)
        params: Visualization parameters including metrics, groupby, time_range, etc.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created chart information including its ID

tools.name: superset_chart_update
tools.description:
Update an existing chart

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/{id} PUT endpoint to update
    chart properties and visualization settings.

    Args:
        chart_id: ID of the chart to update
        data: Data to update, can include slice_name, description, viz_type, params, etc.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the updated chart information

tools.name: superset_chart_delete
tools.description:
Delete a chart

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/chart/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a chart.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone.

    Args:
        chart_id: ID of the chart to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_database_list
tools.description:
Get a list of databases from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/ endpoint to retrieve all database
    connections the current user has access to. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing database connection information including id, name, and configuration

tools.name: superset_database_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific database connection.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete database configuration information

tools.name: superset_database_create
tools.description:
Create a new database connection in Superset

    IMPORTANT: Don't call this tool, unless user have given connection details. This function will only create database connections with explicit user consent and input.
    No default values or assumptions will be made without user confirmation. All connection parameters,
    including sensitive credentials, must be explicitly provided by the user.

    Makes a POST request to /api/v1/database/ to create a new database connection in Superset.
    The endpoint requires a valid SQLAlchemy URI and database configuration parameters.
    The engine parameter will be automatically determined from the SQLAlchemy URI prefix if not specified:
    - 'postgresql://' -> engine='postgresql'
    - 'mysql://' -> engine='mysql'
    - 'mssql://' -> engine='mssql'
    - 'oracle://' -> engine='oracle'
    - 'sqlite://' -> engine='sqlite'

    The SQLAlchemy URI must follow the format: dialect+driver://username:password@host:port/database
    If the URI is not provided, the function will prompt for individual connection parameters to construct it.

    All required parameters must be provided and validated before creating the connection.
    The configuration_method parameter should typically be set to 'sqlalchemy_form'.

    Args:
        engine: Database engine (e.g., 'postgresql', 'mysql', etc.)
        configuration_method: Method used for configuration (typically 'sqlalchemy_form')
        database_name: Name for the database connection
        sqlalchemy_uri: SQLAlchemy URI for the connection (e.g., 'postgresql://user:pass@host/db')

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created database connection information including its ID

tools.name: superset_database_get_tables
tools.description:
Get a list of tables for a given database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/tables/ endpoint to retrieve
    all tables available in the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of tables including schema and table name information

tools.name: superset_database_schemas
tools.description:
Get schemas for a specific database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/schemas/ endpoint to retrieve
    all schemas available in the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of schema names

tools.name: superset_database_test_connection
tools.description:
Test a database connection

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/test_connection endpoint to verify if
    the provided connection details can successfully connect to the database.

    Args:
        database_data: Database connection details including sqlalchemy_uri and other parameters

    Returns:
        A dictionary with connection test results

tools.name: superset_database_update
tools.description:
Update an existing database connection

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id} PUT endpoint to update
    database connection properties.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to update
        data: Data to update, can include database_name, sqlalchemy_uri, password, and extra configs

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the updated database information

tools.name: superset_database_delete
tools.description:
Delete a database connection

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a database connection.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone. This will also remove associated datasets.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_database_get_catalogs
tools.description:
Get all catalogs from a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/catalogs/ endpoint to retrieve
    all catalogs available in the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of catalog names for databases that support catalogs

tools.name: superset_database_get_connection
tools.description:
Get database connection information

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/connection endpoint to retrieve
    connection details for a specific database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with detailed connection information

tools.name: superset_database_get_function_names
tools.description:
Get function names supported by a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/function_names/ endpoint to retrieve
    all SQL functions supported by the database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with list of supported function names

tools.name: superset_database_get_related_objects
tools.description:
Get charts and dashboards associated with a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/related_objects/ endpoint to retrieve
    counts and references of charts and dashboards that depend on this database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database

    Returns:
        A dictionary with counts and lists of related charts and dashboards

tools.name: superset_database_validate_sql
tools.description:
Validate arbitrary SQL against a database

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/{id}/validate_sql/ endpoint to check
    if the provided SQL is valid for the specified database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database
        sql: SQL query to validate

    Returns:
        A dictionary with validation results

tools.name: superset_database_validate_parameters
tools.description:
Validate database connection parameters

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/database/validate_parameters/ endpoint to verify
    if the provided connection parameters are valid without creating a connection.

    Args:
        parameters: Connection parameters to validate

    Returns:
        A dictionary with validation results

tools.name: superset_dataset_list
tools.description:
Get a list of datasets from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dataset/ endpoint to retrieve all datasets
    the current user has access to view. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing dataset information including id, table_name, and database

tools.name: superset_dataset_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific dataset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dataset/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific dataset including columns and metrics.

    Args:
        dataset_id: ID of the dataset to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete dataset information

tools.name: superset_dataset_create
tools.description:
Create a new dataset in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/dataset/ POST endpoint to create a new dataset
    from an existing database table or view.

    Args:
        table_name: Name of the physical table in the database
        database_id: ID of the database where the table exists
        schema: Optional database schema name where the table is located
        owners: Optional list of user IDs who should own this dataset

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created dataset information including its ID

tools.name: superset_sqllab_execute_query
tools.description:
Execute a SQL query in SQL Lab

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/execute/ endpoint to run a SQL query
    against the specified database.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database to query
        sql: SQL query to execute

    Returns:
        A dictionary with query results or execution status for async queries

tools.name: superset_sqllab_get_saved_queries
tools.description:
Get a list of saved queries from SQL Lab

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/saved_query/ endpoint to retrieve all saved queries
    the current user has access to. Results are paginated.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing saved query information including id, label, and database

tools.name: superset_sqllab_format_sql
tools.description:
Format a SQL query for better readability

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/format_sql endpoint to apply standard
    formatting rules to the provided SQL query.

    Args:
        sql: SQL query to format

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the formatted SQL

tools.name: superset_sqllab_get_results
tools.description:
Get results of a previously executed SQL query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/results/ endpoint to retrieve results
    for an asynchronous query using its result key.

    Args:
        key: Result key to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with query results including column information and data rows

tools.name: superset_sqllab_estimate_query_cost
tools.description:
Estimate the cost of executing a SQL query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/estimate endpoint to get approximate cost
    information for a query before executing it.

    Args:
        database_id: ID of the database
        sql: SQL query to estimate
        schema: Optional schema name

    Returns:
        A dictionary with estimated query cost metrics

tools.name: superset_sqllab_export_query_results
tools.description:
Export the results of a SQL query to CSV

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/export/{client_id} endpoint to download
    query results in CSV format.

    Args:
        client_id: Client ID of the query

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the exported data or error information

tools.name: superset_sqllab_get_bootstrap_data
tools.description:
Get the bootstrap data for SQL Lab

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/sqllab/ endpoint to retrieve configuration data
    needed for the SQL Lab interface.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with SQL Lab configuration including allowed databases and settings

tools.name: superset_saved_query_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific saved query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/saved_query/{id} endpoint to retrieve information
    about a saved SQL query.

    Args:
        query_id: ID of the saved query to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the saved query details including SQL text and database

tools.name: superset_saved_query_create
tools.description:
Create a new saved query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/saved_query/ POST endpoint to save a SQL query
    for later reuse.

    Args:
        query_data: Dictionary containing the query information including:
                   - db_id: Database ID
                   - schema: Schema name (optional)
                   - sql: SQL query text
                   - label: Display name for the saved query
                   - description: Optional description of the query

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created saved query information including its ID

tools.name: superset_query_stop
tools.description:
Stop a running query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/query/stop endpoint to terminate a query that
    is currently running.

    Args:
        client_id: Client ID of the query to stop

    Returns:
        A dictionary with confirmation of query termination

tools.name: superset_query_list
tools.description:
Get a list of queries from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/query/ endpoint to retrieve query history.
    Results are paginated and include both finished and running queries.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing query information including status, duration, and SQL

tools.name: superset_query_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific query

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/query/{id} endpoint to retrieve detailed
    information about a specific query execution.

    Args:
        query_id: ID of the query to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with complete query execution information

tools.name: superset_activity_get_recent
tools.description:
Get recent activity data for the current user

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/log/recent_activity/ endpoint to retrieve
    a history of actions performed by the current user.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with recent user activities including viewed charts and dashboards

tools.name: superset_user_get_current
tools.description:
Get information about the currently authenticated user

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/me/ endpoint to retrieve the user's profile
    information including permissions and preferences.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with user profile data

tools.name: superset_user_get_roles
tools.description:
Get roles for the current user

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/me/roles/ endpoint to retrieve all roles
    assigned to the current user.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with user role information

tools.name: superset_tag_list
tools.description:
Get a list of tags from Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/ endpoint to retrieve all tags
    defined in the Superset instance.

    Returns:
        A dictionary containing tag information including id and name

tools.name: superset_tag_create
tools.description:
Create a new tag in Superset

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/ POST endpoint to create a new tag
    that can be applied to objects like charts and dashboards.

    Args:
        name: Name for the tag

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the created tag information

tools.name: superset_tag_get_by_id
tools.description:
Get details for a specific tag

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/{id} endpoint to retrieve information
    about a specific tag.

    Args:
        tag_id: ID of the tag to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with tag details

tools.name: superset_tag_objects
tools.description:
Get objects associated with tags

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/get_objects/ endpoint to retrieve
    all objects that have tags assigned to them.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with tagged objects grouped by tag

tools.name: superset_tag_delete
tools.description:
Delete a tag

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/tag/{id} DELETE endpoint to remove a tag.
    This operation is permanent and cannot be undone.

    Args:
        tag_id: ID of the tag to delete

    Returns:
        A dictionary with deletion confirmation message

tools.name: superset_tag_object_add
tools.description:
Add a tag to an object

    Makes a request to tag an object with a specific tag. This creates an association
    between the tag and the specified object (chart, dashboard, etc.)

    Args:
        object_type: Type of the object ('chart', 'dashboard', etc.)
        object_id: ID of the object to tag
        tag_name: Name of the tag to apply

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the tagging confirmation

tools.name: superset_tag_object_remove
tools.description:
Remove a tag from an object

    Makes a request to remove a tag association from a specific object.

    Args:
        object_type: Type of the object ('chart', 'dashboard', etc.)
        object_id: ID of the object to untag
        tag_name: Name of the tag to remove

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the untagging confirmation message

tools.name: superset_explore_form_data_create
tools.description:
Create form data for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/form_data POST endpoint to store
    chart configuration data temporarily.

    Args:
        form_data: Chart configuration including datasource, metrics, and visualization settings

    Returns:
        A dictionary with a key that can be used to retrieve the form data

tools.name: superset_explore_form_data_get
tools.description:
Get form data for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/form_data/{key} endpoint to retrieve
    previously stored chart configuration.

    Args:
        key: Key of the form data to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the stored chart configuration

tools.name: superset_explore_permalink_create
tools.description:
Create a permalink for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/permalink POST endpoint to generate
    a shareable link to a specific chart exploration state.

    Args:
        state: State data for the permalink including form_data

    Returns:
        A dictionary with a key that can be used to access the permalink

tools.name: superset_explore_permalink_get
tools.description:
Get a permalink for chart exploration

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/explore/permalink/{key} endpoint to retrieve
    a previously saved exploration state.

    Args:
        key: Key of the permalink to retrieve

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the stored exploration state

tools.name: superset_menu_get
tools.description:
Get the Superset menu data

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/menu/ endpoint to retrieve the navigation
    menu structure based on user permissions.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with menu items and their configurations

tools.name: superset_config_get_base_url
tools.description:
Get the base URL of the Superset instance

    Returns the configured Superset base URL that this MCP server is connecting to.
    This can be useful for constructing full URLs to Superset resources or for
    displaying information about the connected instance.

    This tool does not require authentication as it only returns configuration information.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the Superset base URL

tools.name: superset_advanced_data_type_convert
tools.description:
Convert a value to an advanced data type

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/advanced_data_type/convert endpoint to transform
    a value into the specified advanced data type format.

    Args:
        type_name: Name of the advanced data type
        value: Value to convert

    Returns:
        A dictionary with the converted value

tools.name: superset_advanced_data_type_list
tools.description:
Get list of available advanced data types

    Makes a request to the /api/v1/advanced_data_type/types endpoint to retrieve
    all advanced data types supported by this Superset instance.

    Returns:
        A dictionary with available advanced data types and their configurations

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is focused on integrating with and controlling Apache Superset, a popular open-source data visualization platform. It provides a comprehensive suite of tools to programmatically interact with Superset's core functionalities including dashboard management, chart creation and modification, database operations (listing, creating, updating, deleting), SQL query execution and management, data exploration configuration, authentication handling, and user management. The server enables AI agents to handle these operations via natural language requests, streamlining data exploration and visualization workflows.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality is focused on data visualization and management through Superset integration. The secondary categories reflect the server's additional capabilities in database operations and SQL query processing. The custom label highlights the unique aspect of enabling AI agents to control Superset programmatically.

metadata.question: I'm preparing a quarterly sales analysis report for our executive management meeting next week and need to set up the complete visualization system. I've developed a configuration for a complex multi-series line chart that will display sales performance across our four regional markets over the past 12 months. The chart configuration breaks down sales by product category and includes trend markers for each region. My dataset contains the following columns: date, region, sales_amount, product_category, and sales_rep. Before I commit to the full dashboard setup, I need to validate that my chart configuration is correctly structured and will render properly with my data. After I confirm the visualization is valid, I need to create a new dashboard in our business intelligence platform titled "Q4 2024 Regional Sales Performance Dashboard" with a default grid layout and pre-configured filtering options for the four regions. The dashboard should include metadata specifying a dark color scheme optimized for projector presentations during the meeting. Can you first validate my chart configuration to ensure everything is working correctly, and then proceed to create the dashboard container? Please return the dashboard ID after creation so I can track it in our project documentation system.
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary purposes in a data visualization workflow. The validate_chart_code tool from Vizro is designed for rapid prototyping and validation of individual chart configurations, ensuring that visualization code and data structure are correct before deployment. The superset_dashboard_create tool from Superset Integration creates dashboard containers in an enterprise BI platform, which serves as the deployment environment for validated visualizations. Together, they support the complete workflow from chart development and validation to dashboard infrastructure crÃ©ation and deployment, which is essential for Statistical Assistants preparing client-facing reports.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with validating the chart configuration to ensure the visualization code is properly structured and compatible with the data structure. This validation step catches any issues early before deployment resources are committed. Once the chart configuration is confirmed as valid, the workflow proceeds to create the dashboard container in the BI platform where this visualization (and potentially others) will be published. The validation provides confidence that the chart will work correctly when integrated into the dashboard.

messages.content: I am preparing a competitiveness assessment for the Board of Directors regarding our CEO's compensation package relative to the technology sector. To complete this analysis, could you retrieve the detailed compensation breakdownâ€”including salary, bonus, and stock awardsâ€”for NVIDIA's top executives? Additionally, I need the current industry benchmark data for the technology sector to compare our internal pay structure against market averages.

server_info.name: Financial Modeling Prep (FMP) Server
server_info.author: @imbenrabi/financial-modeling-prep-mcp-server
server_info.overview: Provide AI assistants with comprehensive access to financial data, stock information, company fundamentals, and market insights. Enable seamless querying and analysis of financial metrics, market indexes, news, and more through a standardized protocol. Empower financial decision-making with real-time and historical data integration. NOTE: some tools require paid API key, see https://site.financialmodelingprep.com/developer/docs for more info.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@imbenrabi/financial-modeling-prep-mcp-server/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

metadata.target_tools: Financial Modeling Prep (FMP) Server::getExecutiveCompensation, Financial Modeling Prep (FMP) Server::getExecutiveCompensationBenchmark
metadata.question: I am preparing a competitiveness assessment for the Board of Directors regarding our CEO's compensation package relative to the technology sector. To complete this analysis, could you retrieve the detailed compensation breakdownâ€”including salary, bonus, and stock awardsâ€”for NVIDIA's top executives? Additionally, I need the current industry benchmark data for the technology sector to compare our internal pay structure against market averages.
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary functions within the compensation analysis workflow. The first tool, `getExecutiveCompensation`, provides granular, company-specific data detailing the exact salary, stock awards, and total compensation packages for specific executives within a firm. The second tool, `getExecutiveCompensationBenchmark`, provides macro-level data, offering industry-wide averages and prevailing wage rates. To perform a complete competitiveness analysis, an analyst must use the first tool to understand the "internal state" of executive pay and the second tool to understand the "external market" context. Without the specific company data, there is nothing to benchmark, and without the benchmark data, the specific company figures lack context for competitive assessment.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins by retrieving the specific compensation figures for a target company's executives (e.g., the CEO) to determine the current pay structure and total value. This data is then synthesized by retrieving industry benchmark data to establish a baseline for what is considered standard or competitive in that specific sector. The user compares the specific output from the first step against the aggregated output from the second step to identify gaps, overages, or trends, supporting a recommendation for compensation adjustments or policy changes.

First, please pull up the detailed syllabus and section information for this course from our main class portal so I can remind myself of the specific learning outcomes for this semester. Second, please retrieve Marcus's specific submission for the most recent "Fabric Analysis Lab" from the grading systemâ€”you'll need to look up course ID 98765 and assignment ID 10203â€”so I can assess his practical work alongside the course requirements during our discussion.

server_info.name: Canvas MCP
server_info.author: @aryankeluskar/canvas-mcp
server_info.overview: EdTech MCP. This is a collection of Canvas LMS tools for the model context protocol. Allows you to query your courses and get help for your assignments in the AI app of your choice. try now!
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "canvasApiKey": "",
  "googleApiKey": "",
  "gradescopeEmail": "",
  "gradescopePassword": ""
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@aryankeluskar/canvas-mcp/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

tools.name: get_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary mapping course names to their corresponding IDs. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names, display all available courses, or when needing to access any course-related information.

tools.name: get_modules
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all modules within a specific Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module objects containing module details like ID, name, and status. Use this when exploring or navigating course content structure.

tools.name: get_module_items
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all items within a specific module in a Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module item objects containing details like title, type, and URLs. Use this when you need to access specific learning materials, assignments, or other content within a module.

tools.name: get_file_url
tools.description: Use this tool to get the direct download URL for a file stored in Canvas. This tool returns a URL string that can be used to access or download the file. Use this when you need direct access to file content rather than just the Canvas page URL.

tools.name: find_resources
tools.description: Use this tool to search for and identify the most relevant learning resources across Canvas courses based on a text query or image. This tool analyzes user needs and returns resources ranked by relevance. Use this when helping users find specific learning materials, lecture notes, or content related to their questions.

tools.name: get_course_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Canvas course, with optional filtering by status. This tool returns assignment details including name, description, due date, and submission status. Use this when helping users manage their coursework, check due dates, or find assignment details.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Canvas course ID
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_assignments_by_course_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a Canvas course using its name rather than ID. This tool returns assignment details the same as get_course_assignments. Use this when you have the course name but not the ID, or when helping users find assignments across multiple courses.
    
    Args:
        course_name: The name of the course as it appears in Canvas (partial matches supported)
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_canvas_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This is an alias for get_courses. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names or display all available courses.

tools.name: get_gradescope_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Gradescope courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary of courses organized by user role. Use this when helping users access or manage their Gradescope course information.

tools.name: get_gradescope_course_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope course by name (partial matches supported). This tool returns the course object if found. Use this when you need to get course details or ID when only the name is known.
    
    Args:
        course_name: The name or partial name of the Gradescope course to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Gradescope course. This tool returns a list of assignment objects with details like name, due date, and status. Use this when helping users manage their Gradescope coursework.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignment_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope assignment by name within a course. This tool returns the assignment object if found. Use this when you need assignment details or ID when only the name and course are known.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_name: The name or partial name of the assignment to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_submissions
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all submissions for a specific Gradescope assignment. This tool returns a list of submission objects with details like submission time and score. Use this when helping users review or manage submission information.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_student_submission
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve a specific student's submission for a Gradescope assignment. This tool returns the submission object if found. Use this when helping a student review their own submission or when an instructor needs details about a specific student's work.
    
    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID
        student_email: The email address of the student whose submission to retrieve

tools.name: call_search_gradescope
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool analyzes the query and returns relevant information about courses, assignments, or submissions. Use this when helping users find Gradescope information without knowing specific IDs or technical details.
    
    Args:
        query: Natural language query about Gradescope courses, assignments, etc.

tools.name: search_education_platforms
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across both Canvas and Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool determines which platform is most relevant to the query and returns appropriately formatted results. Use this for broad educational queries when the user hasn't specified which platform they're interested in.
    
    Args:
        query: Natural language query about courses, assignments, or other educational content

metadata.question: I am preparing for a one-on-one academic review session with my student, Marcus Lee (marcus.lee@university.edu), regarding his progress in my "Textiles and Apparel Design" course. To get a full picture before we meet, I need you to perform two tasks. metadata.tool_analysis: The first tool, `course-details`, allows retrieval of comprehensive course information such as syllabi and structure from Google Classroom, which aligns with the task of preparing course materials and understanding the context of a class. The second tool, `get_gradescope_student_submission`, enables specific access to a student's submitted work on Gradescope, directly supporting the task of evaluating and grading student assignments. The instructor first retrieves the details for a specific course to review the learning objectives, assignment criteria, or syllabus requirements. Once the context is understood, the instructor then retrieves the specific student's submission from Gradescope for a designated assignment. This allows the instructor to evaluate the student's work directly against the course standards retrieved in the first step, ensuring that grading or feedback is consistent with the course expectations.

metadata.question: I'm designing a custom wooden framework assembly for an elevator shaft support structure. I need to model two timber beamsâ€”a 6-foot horizontal rail and a 4-foot vertical supportâ€”that will be joined together perpendicular to each other. Can you help me create this assembly by first setting up each beam as a separate reusable component based on these dimensions, and then joining them together using a traditional interlocking woodworking joint that provides strong mechanical connection and resists pulling forces?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools available from the Sketchup Integration server serve complementary functions in a 3D modeling workflow for structural design. The `create_component` tool allows users to define reusable 3D parts or objects, which is essential for modeling prefabricated sections like framework, rails, and other components based on specifications from blueprints. The `create_dovetail` tool then enables the creation of dovetail joints between these componentsâ€”a traditional woodworking joinery technique that creates strong mechanical connections. Together, these tools support the workflow of designing structural assemblies where individual components are first defined and then joined together, which directly maps to tasks performed by Elevator and Escalator Installers when planning and visualizing framework assemblies.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow follows a logical sequence: First, the user needs to create the individual structural components as separate reusable entities in the 3D modeling environment. This corresponds to the task of creating prefabricated sections of framework and rails. Once these components exist, they need to be connected using a strong interlocking joint. The dovetail joint is then created between the two components to establish the mechanical connection. This mirrors real-world assembly processes where components are fabricated first and then joined together during installation.

The available tools enable a wide range of design operations, including node manipulation, text content modification, style management, component handling, and prototyping connections. labels.reasoning: The primary functionality of automating and programmatically modifying design elements in Figma clearly aligns with the "Design & Prototyping" category, which is a custom label as it represents a unique domain. metadata.question: I'm working on designing a new briefing screen for our RPG's side quest system, and I have the current layout mockup selected in Figma. I need to first examine the selected UI elements to understand the text field dimensions, character limits, and visual styling constraints, then get recommendations for writing compelling quest briefing prompts that deliver mission objectives clearly while fitting within those design specifications and maintaining our game's adventure narrative tone.
metadata.tool_analysis: The first tool (get_general_suggestions from RT-Prompt) specializes in providing prompt engineering suggestions to enhance LLM-generated content for various development and design tasks. For a video game designer, this is particularly useful for tasks related to writing game text/dialogue, generating game design ideas, and crafting presentations. The second tool (read_my_design from Cursor Talk to Figma) provides detailed information about currently selected elements in Figma, enabling designers to understand design constraints, layout details, and UI specifications. These tools work together because the Figma design information (constraints, dimensions, styling) provides essential context that informs the prompt suggestions for content creation that must fit within those design specifications.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with examining the current Figma design selection to understand the visual and technical constraints of the game UI element (such as dialogue boxes, mission briefings, or menu layouts). This design informationâ€”including text dimensions, available space, and styling elementsâ€”is then used as context when requesting prompt suggestions. The prompt suggestions are tailored to create content that fits seamlessly within the established design framework while engaging players effectively. This is particularly valuable when creating dialogue content, mission descriptions, or interface text that must adhere to specific UI constraints while maintaining narrative quality.

messages.content: I am conducting a comprehensive review for a report on the safety implications of incorporating recycled materials into food packaging. To keep my knowledge current, I need to gather research from two different angles. First, I need to find recent academic papers discussing the regulatory frameworks and technological feasibility of using post-consumer recycled content in manufacturing. Second, I need to find biomedical studies that specifically investigate the potential migration of chemical contaminants from recycled plastics and their subsequent effects on human endocrine function. Can you search for literature covering both the industry policy standards and the specific toxicological health risks?

Can you search for literature covering both the industry policy standards and the specific toxicological health risks?
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools complement each other by covering distinct but overlapping domains necessary for a comprehensive literature review within Industrial Ecology. The Semantic Scholar tool via 'papers-search-basic' is best suited for finding broad academic literature regarding technology, economics, and public policy surrounding industrial processes. The PubMed tool, 'search_pubmed_key_words', is specialized for biomedical literature, which is essential for researching the human health impacts and toxicological consequences associated with those industrial materials and processes. Using both allows the user to bridge the gap between industrial implementation/policy and public health outcomes, fulfilling the occupational task of reviewing research literature across physical science and public policy.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: To solve the user's request, the workflow will first query the Semantic Scholar tool to locate papers focusing on the technological, economic, and policy aspects of the specific industrial practice (e.g., circular economy initiatives, recycling standards, or material science). Subsequently, the workflow will query the PubMed tool to locate biomedical research papers focusing on the specific toxicological, epidemiological, or physiological effects linked to the materials or processes identified in the first search. This ensures a holistic view of the topic from both an industrial and a medical perspective.

After I have this market research and finalize our hiring plan, I need to set up an automated process to requisition all the necessary equipment and supplies for the new team membersâ€”including custom uniforms, safety gear, communication devices, and training materials. Can you help me first gather the relevant job market data, and then create an automated workflow for handling all the equipment and supply requisitions?

server_info.name: MCP Server
server_info.author: @Rapiernik/mcp-server
server_info.overview: Integrate your applications with external data and tools seamlessly. Enhance your LLM capabilities by allowing them to interact with real-world resources and perform actions dynamically. Simplify the process of building intelligent applications with standardized protocols.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@Rapiernik/mcp-server/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

server_info.name: Canvas Integration Server
server_info.author: @jpablomm/mcp-hackathon-canvas
server_info.overview: Enable AI agents to interact seamlessly with Canvas LMS and Gradescope by querying courses, assignments, modules, and calendar events using natural language. Access detailed breakdowns of upcoming assignments and submission statuses to streamline educational workflows. Enhance your productivity by integrating these educational platforms directly into your AI assistant environment.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "canvasApiKey": "",
  "googleApiKey": "",
  "gradescopeEmail": "",
  "gradescopePassword": ""
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@jpablomm/mcp-hackathon-canvas/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

tools.name: get_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary mapping course names to their corresponding IDs. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names, display all available courses, or when needing to access any course-related information.

tools.name: get_modules
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all modules within a specific Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module objects containing module details like ID, name, and status. Use this when exploring or navigating course content structure.

tools.name: get_module_items
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all items within a specific module in a Canvas course. This tool returns a list of module item objects containing details like title, type, and URLs. Use this when you need to access specific learning materials, assignments, or other content within a module.

tools.name: get_file_url
tools.description: Use this tool to get the direct download URL for a file stored in Canvas. This tool returns a URL string that can be used to access or download the file. Use this when you need direct access to file content rather than just the Canvas page URL.

tools.name: find_resources
tools.description: Use this tool to search for and identify the most relevant learning resources across Canvas courses based on a text query or image. This tool analyzes user needs and returns resources ranked by relevance. Use this when helping users find specific learning materials, lecture notes, or content related to their questions.

tools.name: get_course_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Canvas course, with optional filtering by status. This tool returns assignment details including name, description, due date, and submission status. Use this when helping users manage their coursework, check due dates, or find assignment details.

    Args:
        course_id: The Canvas course ID
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_assignments_by_course_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a Canvas course using its name rather than ID. This tool returns assignment details the same as get_course_assignments. Use this when you have the course name but not the ID, or when helping users find assignments across multiple courses.

    Args:
        course_name: The name of the course as it appears in Canvas (partial matches supported)
        bucket: Optional filter - past, overdue, undated, ungraded, unsubmitted, upcoming, future

tools.name: get_canvas_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Canvas courses for the current user. This is an alias for get_courses. Use this when you need to find course IDs based on names or display all available courses.

tools.name: get_gradescope_courses
tools.description: Use this tool to retrieve all available Gradescope courses for the current user. This tool returns a dictionary of courses organized by user role. Use this when helping users access or manage their Gradescope course information.

tools.name: get_gradescope_course_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope course by name (partial matches supported). This tool returns the course object if found. Use this when you need to get course details or ID when only the name is known.

    Args:
        course_name: The name or partial name of the Gradescope course to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignments
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all assignments for a specific Gradescope course. This tool returns a list of assignment objects with details like name, due date, and status. Use this when helping users manage their Gradescope coursework.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_assignment_by_name
tools.description:
Use this tool to find a specific Gradescope assignment by name within a course. This tool returns the assignment object if found. Use this when you need assignment details or ID when only the name and course are known.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_name: The name or partial name of the assignment to search for

tools.name: get_gradescope_submissions
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve all submissions for a specific Gradescope assignment. This tool returns a list of submission objects with details like submission time and score. Use this when helping users review or manage submission information.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID

tools.name: get_gradescope_student_submission
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve a specific student's submission for a Gradescope assignment. This tool returns the submission object if found. Use this when helping a student review their own submission or when an instructor needs details about a specific student's work.

    Args:
        course_id: The Gradescope course ID
        assignment_id: The Gradescope assignment ID
        student_email: The email address of the student whose submission to retrieve

tools.name: call_search_gradescope
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool analyzes the query and returns relevant information about courses, assignments, or submissions. Use this when helping users find Gradescope information without knowing specific IDs or technical details.

    Args:
        query: Natural language query about Gradescope courses, assignments, etc.

tools.name: search_education_platforms
tools.description:
Use this tool to search for information across both Canvas and Gradescope using natural language queries. This tool determines which platform is most relevant to the query and returns appropriately formatted results. Use this for broad educational queries when the user hasn't specified which platform they're interested in.

    Args:
        query: Natural language query about courses, assignments, or other educational content

A custom label was not deemed necessary as the functionality is well-captured by the predefined categories.

metadata.question: I'm an Occupational Therapy Assistant working toward my advanced certification in sensory integration therapy. I'm enrolled in continuing education courses through both my healthcare organization's internal training program and an external accredited continuing education provider. I need to thoroughly prepare for my certification exam next month and want to ensure I have access to all available learning materials. Could you help me find comprehensive study resources, lecture notes, and reference materials covering sensory processing assessment tools, vestibular and proprioceptive interventions, and evidence-based treatment approaches across all my active courses? I want to make sure I don't miss anything important from either program.
metadata.tool_analysis: Both tools are named "find_resources" and provide similar functionality for searching learning resources across Canvas LMS platforms, but they originate from different MCP servers (Canvas Integration Server and Canvas MCP). The Canvas Integration Server specializes in natural language interactions to streamline educational workflows, while the Canvas MCP focuses on efficient EdTech integration within AI applications. Together, these tools allow comprehensive searching across potentially different Canvas instances or educational platforms that an Occupational Therapy Assistant might access for continuing education. The complementary nature of these tools ensures that all relevant learning materials from multiple sources can be identified and compiled for thorough preparation.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow involves searching the same or related educational content queries across two separate Canvas-based platforms to which the OTA has access. First, the find_resources tool from Canvas Integration Server would be used to search for course materials, lecture notes, and study resources related to continuing education topics in one learning environment. Then, the find_resources tool from Canvas MCP would be used to conduct a parallel search for similar or complementary materials in a second learning environment (such as an external continuing education provider). This dual-search approach ensures comprehensive coverage of all available educational materials across different platforms, which is essential for thorough exam preparation and skill development.

messages.content: I'm implementing a new SMS notification system for payment reminders at our billing department. labels.analysis: The MCP Server is a comprehensive CRM (Customer Relationship Management) data management system specifically designed for integration with HubSpot. It provides tools to create, read, update, and delete various CRM entities (companies, contacts, leads, products, etc.) as well as handle associations between these entities. It supports batch operations for efficiency, advanced search capabilities, and engagement management (like meetings, calls, emails, tasks, and notes). The server also manages communication preferences and handles product-related operations. The core functionality revolves around streamlining CRM operations through a well-structured API interface with type-safe validation and support for all major CRM entities.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Database Operations" is chosen because the server's main functionality involves managing and interacting with CRM data, including CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on various entities, batch processing, and search capabilities. This aligns closely with database management activities. Secondary labels "API Integration" and "Communication Tools" are added because the server provides extensive API tools for interacting with HubSpot CRM and includes tools for managing communications (emails, calls, notes). No custom label is needed as the predefined labels adequately cover the server's functionality.

server_info.name: HubSpot MCP
server_info.author: @shinzo-labs/hubspot-mcp
server_info.overview:
Access and manage your CRM data seamlessly with 100+ tools in our HubSpot MCP implementation including manipulation of Contacts, Companies, and Associations.

Follow the steps here to get a free Developer API Key (save as HUBSPOT_ACCESS_TOKEN): https://developers.hubspot.com/docs/guides/api/overview
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@shinzo-labs/hubspot-mcp/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

labels.analysis: The MCP Server provides a comprehensive set of tools for interacting with HubSpot's CRM platform, enabling users to manage contacts, companies, associations, meetings, notes, tasks, calls, emails, communications preferences, products, and other CRM objects. The tools focus on CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations, batch processing, searching, and filtering capabilities, all designed to streamline CRM data management and workflow automation.
labels.reasoning: The primary functionality revolves around CRM data management and operations, which aligns best with the "Database Operations" category. Additionally, the server includes tools for managing meetings, tasks, and communications, which fits within "Daily Productivity" and "API Integration" categories due to its API-first approach.

metadata.target_tools: HubSpot CRM API Server::crm_create_contact_property, HubSpot MCP::communications_get_preferences
metadata.question: I'm implementing a new SMS notification system for payment reminders at our billing department. I need to first add a custom field to our contact records where we can track whether each customer has consented to receive SMS billing notifications. After creating this new tracking field, I need to review the current communication preferences for our active customers to see how they're currently set up, so we can identify who might be interested in opting into this new notification method.
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools complement each other in a customer communication management workflow. The first tool (crm_create_contact_property) is an administrative function that modifies the contact database schema by adding new property definitions - this is essential for expanding the types of information tracked about customers. The second tool (communications_get_preferences) retrieves actual data about how contacts prefer to be communicated with. Together, they enable a billing clerk to first expand the data capture capabilities of the CRM system, then review existing communication settings to understand current customer preferences. This supports the task of contacting customers to obtain or relay account information by ensuring the system can properly track consent and by enabling review of current preferences.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with creating a new custom property on contact records to track additional information (such as SMS consent for billing notifications). Once this new tracking capability is in place, the clerk retrieves the communication preferences for contacts to review their current settings. This two-step process allows the clerk to both establish the infrastructure needed for new communication channels and understand how customers are currently configured, enabling effective customer outreach strategies.

messages.content: I'm preparing a comprehensive proposal package for our spring season window display campaign that needs to be presented to senior management next week. I need to create an efficient system for generating creative display concepts that I can use across multiple store locations, and then build an impressive digital presentation to showcase these concepts. Can you help me first create a prompt template workflow that will help me consistently generate display ideas including seasonal themes, coordinated color schemes, recommended props, and layout sketches? Once I have those creative foundations in place, I'll also need the implementation details for text reveal animations to incorporate eye-catching animated product messaging into my presentation materials.

server_info.name: Prompt Server
server_info.author: @Lengbumo/mcp-prompt-server
server_info.overview: Provide a rich collection of high-quality prompt templates as MCP tools to streamline your AI workflows. Use natural language to invoke prompts for tasks like code generation, writing, product design, and data visualization without manual copy-pasting. Easily extend and manage prompts with hot-reloading and multi-language support for diverse applications.
server_info.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@Lengbumo/mcp-prompt-server/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())

labels.analysis: The MCP Server is designed to streamline AI workflows by providing a collection of pre-defined prompt templates for various tasks such as code generation, writing, product design, and data visualization. It emphasizes natural language invocation of these templates, eliminating the need for manual copy-pasting. The available tools indicate a focus on content generation, template management, and dynamic reloading of prompts. The server's capabilities align closely with productivity enhancement and content creation tasks.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Content Creation" was chosen because the server's tools are predominantly focused on generating various forms of content (HTML pages, podcast scripts, summaries, etc.). The secondary label "AI/ML Tools" was selected because the server leverages AI prompts extensively. The secondary label "Development Tools" was included because some tools like "gen_3d_webpage_html" and "gen_prd_prototype_html" suggest applications in web and product development.

Simplify UI creation by leveraging categorized tools for efficient component retrieval and usage.

labels.analysis: The MCP Server focuses on providing a rich library of UI components, special effects, animations, and device mocks specifically designed for enhancing user interface development. Its tools cater to developers and designers by offering detailed implementation information for pre-built UI elements, categorized for easy retrieval and integration. The server's primary purpose is to simplify and streamline the UI creation process by offering a comprehensive collection of interactive and visually appealing components.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Content Creation" is chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around providing tools for creating and enhancing UI elements, which directly supports the process of UI/UX designâ€”a subset of content creation. The secondary label "Development Tools" is included because the server provides implementation details and components that are directly useful for developers. A custom label "UI Design Components" is added to highlight the server's unique focus on providing a vast library of UI-specific elements and animations.

metadata.target_tools: Prompt Server::build_mcp_server, Magic UI Component Server::getTextReveal
metadata.question: I'm preparing a comprehensive proposal package for our spring season window display campaign that needs to be presented to senior management next week. I need to create an efficient system for generating creative display concepts that I can use across multiple store locations, and then build an impressive digital presentation to showcase these concepts. Can you help me first create a prompt template workflow that will help me consistently generate display ideas including seasonal themes, coordinated color schemes, recommended props, and layout sketches? Once I have those creative foundations in place, I'll also need the implementation details for text reveal animations to incorporate eye-catching animated product messaging into my presentation materials.
metadata.tool_analysis: The two tools serve complementary purposes in the workflow of a Merchandise Displayer creating a comprehensive display proposal. Tool 1 (build_mcp_server) from Prompt Server enables the creation of streamlined workflow templates for generating creative content, ideas, and planning documents. This aligns with tasks like developing display concepts, selecting themes, and preparing sketches. Tool 2 (getTextReveal) from Magic UI Component Server provides specific UI implementation details for text animation effects, which supports the visual presentation aspect of display planning. Together, they allow a displayer to first establish a systematic approach to creative ideation and then implement striking visual presentations to showcase their concepts to stakeholders.
metadata.cross_tool_workflow: The workflow begins with the user creating a prompt template system to streamline the creative planning process for window displays. This includes generating consistent output for themes, color palettes, prop suggestions, and overall display concepts. messages.content: I'm designing a custom wooden cupola structure that will sit on top of a roof ridge in my 3D modeling software. The main framework has vertical posts that support the horizontal beam (needs a strong load-bearing connection), and the decorative corner trim pieces where the slanted roof sections meet form visible intersecting angles that will be seen from below. I need to create the proper joints between all these timber components to complete the assembly model. Can you help me set up the structural connection between the beam and posts, and then create the interlocking joints for the visible corner pieces?
